post_text:
Does anybody use a mifi or portable Wi-Fi for computer work when not able to connect to other Wi-Fi‚Äôs?

Any recommendations or devices or data plan carriers?

comments.text:
I have a wireless plan for my ipad.
I have t-mobile. I've been very happy with it but it's also very different in different areas as far as coverage.

You have to make sure you have an iPad that is cellular capable. Otherwise a mifi device will work. Each carrier has them

I did not find using my phone as a  hotspot to be very reliable the other thing is when you use your phone as a  hotspot at some point it slows your speed. So if you normally get 4G or 5G or hotspot is often 1G less it depends on your carrier and plan. Plus it uses your battery a lot faster

I also found that when I would walk with my patients outside and I had my phone with me it would disconnect from the hotspot and I had to redo it and it was super annoying and I didn't want to have to think about it.
Documentation is hard enough getting it done while you're with the patient so I didn't want anything to make it harder.

I just checked into this myself last week. I have an iPad I intend to use for my documentation, but it is a Wi-Fi only device. I checked with my carrier and can add unlimited hotspot to my personal cell plan for $20 per month. This is probably the route I‚Äôm going to take. Ôøº

post_text:
I‚Äôm trying to decided between Hellonote & PT Everywhere for EMR; pros & cons (besides hellonote 1/2 price than other ) 

I will be a brick & mortar 1 PT cash based clinic for now beginning Jan 
Thanks for help!!

comments.text: PtEverywhere!! üòâ

PT Everywhere user here in a 1 PT mostly cash-based clinic. They do have some nice features, namely their patient interface that lets the patient fill out intake paperwork ahead of time, but it's not intuitive. The platform in general is also kind of clunky. I can try to design eval or daily note templates, but when they get exported as a pdf (to send to physicians, worker's comp, etc), it gets un-formatted and difficult to decipher. They have a 'help' page, but it's just a huge document that is unsearchable - you have to literally scan through all the text to find the topic you're looking for, and even then, it's often just basic info that's not usable.  There are major issues with being able to see what documents I've emailed or faxed to varioius people, as there is no record of that at all, and there is also no way to save common recipients (so I have to fully enter fax numbers or email address for literally every document).    If I were doing it again, I would elect to use the cheaper option, as the patient interface ability is simply not worth it for me. Maybe if I had more time to figure out the program, I might be able to use some of the other features, but as it is, it just takes too many steps to write a note and get a legible copy and CMS1500 form over to payors.

COMMENT 2: PT Everywhere user here in a 1 PT mostly cash-based clinic. They do have some nice features, namely their patient interface that lets the patient fill out intake paperwork ahead of time, but it's not intuitive. The platform in general is also kind of clunky. I can try to design eval or daily note templates, but when they get exported as a pdf (to send to physicians, worker's comp, etc), it gets un-formatted and difficult to decipher. They have a 'help' page, but it's just a huge document that is unsearchable - you have to literally scan through all the text to find the topic you're looking for, and even then, it's often just basic info that's not usable.  There are major issues with being able to see what documents I've emailed or faxed to varioius people, as there is no record of that at all, and there is also no way to save common recipients (so I have to fully enter fax numbers or email address for literally every document).    If I were doing it again, I would elect to use the cheaper option, as the patient interface ability is simply not worth it for me. Maybe if I had more time to figure out the program, I might be able to use some of the other features, but as it is, it just takes too many steps to write a note and get a legible copy and CMS1500 form over to payors.

post_text: For anyone using Jane App or Simple Practice, how are you faxing/receiving POC's or other patient information? I have an outside fax line and use simple practice but trying to make it more streamlined with how I receive, store and integrate these documents. Thanks!

comments.text: I use Jane and SRFax. I have to download documents from Jane into SRFax to send out. When I receive one, it shows up in email. I then have to upload it into Jane. I have a separate spreadsheet where I track what's been sent and when it comes back. I admit it's a bit of a hassle. I wish Jane had a fax system integrated.

I use Srfax with SimplePractice. Make a chart note when I fax POC for signature and also have a spread sheet of 1st/2nd attempts, when receive signed POC, when cert expires, when D/C and color code. I upload pdf of signed POC (naming document with end date of certification of POC) to patient chart and if needed make ‚Äúother appt‚Äù on the day cert POC is up as another reminder.

full_thread_text:

post_text: Hey crew! thoughts on reaching out to patients who are once a week or once every other week‚Ä¶I‚Äôm mobile cash based PT. Do you reach out to check in and see how patients are doing after a session or just wait til next session? Thanks in advance!

comments.text: Personally I view it as a must.  It‚Äôs an additional thing that separates you from the insurance based clinic around the corner, shows that you actually care about their rehab journey and don‚Äôt view them just as another name, and is helpful regarding exercise changes/modifications that most PTs don‚Äôt get to make until the following week.

I am not cash base but if I were i think that level a follow up would be a great idea. I am working on a telehealth job which I have yet to start but I do know they have some kind of text message system as well. There is some question on hippa compliance so I would make sure they have signed a release stating they are aware that text messaging is not secure. Were there may be a different app system you could use that is considered secure. Something to think about.

full_thread_text:
POST: Hey crew! thoughts on reaching out to patients who are once a week or once every other week‚Ä¶I‚Äôm mobile cash based PT. Do you reach out to check in and see how patients are doing after a session or just wait til next session? Thanks in advance!

COMMENT 1: Personally I view it as a must.  It‚Äôs an additional thing that separates you from the insurance based clinic around the corner, shows that you actually care about their rehab journey and don‚Äôt view them just as another name, and is helpful regarding exercise changes/modifications that most PTs don‚Äôt get to make until the following week.

COMMENT 2: I am not cash base but if I were i think that level a follow up would be a great idea. I am working on a telehealth job which I have yet to start but I do know they have some kind of text message system as well. There is some question on hippa compliance so I would make sure they have signed a release stating they are aware that text messaging is not secure. Were there may be a different app system you could use that is considered secure. Something to think about.

I was wondering if anyone sells/creates EMRs based in Google Workspace.

post_text: In the past, documenting for wellness has been discussed in this group, and it seems to be split down the middle as far as what you should document (nothing vs a simple soap note to CYA). If PT is not being performed, but stretching and general strengthening exercises are (kindof like personal training), is it a bad idea to document very basically what was done (even just body part and basic exercise notes) to jog my memory for the next time? Or should it really just be documented arrival and payment and that‚Äôs it?

comments.text: I document a basic SOAP note for wellness. Most of the time no objective though and the assessment is "No adverse reaction noted". If I didn't have a section for "Services Rendered" then I would put it in the objective.
I used an excel type sheet to just list exercises and reps, much like a trainer would.

full_thread_text:

COMMENT 1: I document a basic SOAP note for wellness. Most of the time no objective though and the assessment is "No adverse reaction noted". If I didn't have a section for "Services Rendered" then I would put it in the objective.

post_text:
For mobile practice owners. 
If you charge a cancellation fee (only for repeat offenders), how much of that goes to your Ic that lost the visit? 
My cancellation fee is almost the same as what I pay my contractors. Just give it all to them?
I need to create a policy around this but wondering what others are doing.

comments.text:
#Compliance #CancellationFee 
Cindy - A cancellation/no show policy should be the same for all patients;  and equally applied across the entire practice.  

How a practice determines compensation for IC (or employees) for "lost revenue" (missed visit) should be separate and distinct from a patient Cancellation/No Show policy.
I give ICs 50% of billed no show and cancellation fees, and my ICs have been fine with that so far!

full_thread_text:

My cancellation fee is almost the same as what I pay my contractors. Just give it all to them?
I need to create a policy around this but wondering what others are doing.

COMMENT 1: #Compliance #CancellationFee 
Cindy - A cancellation/no show policy should be the same for all patients;  and equally applied across the entire practice.  

How a practice determines compensation for IC (or employees) for "lost revenue" (missed visit) should be separate and distinct from a patient Cancellation/No Show policy.

COMMENT 2: I give ICs 50% of billed no show and cancellation fees, and my ICs have been fine with that so far!

Wanted to share a win and a lesson‚Ä¶

I had a client this month tell me before initial eval that he didn‚Äôt think he could afford my services.

I explained a few points about my value and he decided to book the initial eval only.

He ended up purchasing a 4 session package and had amazing outcomes.

Then during the month he was working with me he decided to also invest in a $5,000 home gym.

NEVER apologize for your pricing and what you bring to the table.

Choosing to work with me likely spurred him to invest in his health further 5x what he ever spent in my office.

We are changing people‚Äôs lives‚Ä¶don‚Äôt forget that.

CANCELLATION POLICY
I understand that all appointments must be canceled a minimum of 24 hours before the scheduled appointment start time. post_text: Mobile therapists, do you send the patients paperwork to complete prior to first visit, or do you bring your IPAD to their home and they fill it out there ?

full_thread_text:

post_text: Hi everyone. I received a pre-payment review for 3 dates of service on a patient from Medicare (Pt has Railroad Medicare). Has anyone ever had to do one of these? I keep detailed visit notes, but they want all except for the blood of my first born child üôÑ. Do you suggest I type something up on word that addresses all of these requirements along with my treatment note so the auditor can read it more easily? Any suggestions are welcome! Thank you!

comments.text: Yes, I just went through this and passed/ was paid in full. I provided what they requested (which ultimately was only eval, signed plan of care, daily notes, and progress update as my documentation was adequate to demonstrate medical necessity). I did not send anything extra!

#Compliance #RailroadMedicare Palmetto, the MAC for RR Medicare has initiated a series of "Targeted Probe & Educate" reviews (audits) involving outpatient therapy. 

Suggest reviewing letter very carefully to gather all the items required, and address every item in the documentation request. Palmetto provided education on TPE response in a recent presentation. 

Reach out if you need further information or clarification.

full_thread_text:

Do you suggest I type something up on word that addresses all of these requirements along with my treatment note so the auditor can read it more easily? Any suggestions are welcome! Thank you!

COMMENT 1: Yes, I just went through this and passed/ was paid in full. I provided what they requested (which ultimately was only eval, signed plan of care, daily notes, and progress update as my documentation was adequate to demonstrate medical necessity). I did not send anything extra!

COMMENT 2: #Compliance #RailroadMedicare Palmetto, the MAC for RR Medicare has initiated a series of "Targeted Probe & Educate" reviews (audits) involving outpatient therapy. 

Suggest reviewing letter very carefully to gather all the items required, and address every item in the documentation request. Palmetto provided education on TPE response in a recent presentation. 

Reach out if you need further information or clarification.

post_text:
Anyone else deal with this? 

We do many thousands of visits every year but nearly all are for home health. Recently began accepting cash pay patients. 

At first I was super stoked to just accept a VenMo payment outside of our business. 

But these patients are medically fragile and not without risk. The more I think about it, the more it feels like we need to run them through our business, including documenting every thing in our EMR. 

Am I correct in thinking we should be protecting the rest of our business by using our existing infrastructure for these cases?

comments.text:
I am all cash pay and do full documentation on all my clients. I am still responsible to them to fully assess their condition and provide intervention so I‚Äôm going to document it. 
I‚Äôm not doing the unnecessary check boxes that insurance co ask for but that‚Äôs is not the same as not documenting. 
I think we do our profession a disservice calling/treating wellness sessions as less/unskilled.

I always make a simple SOAP note in my EMR. Like someone said above, they're much shorter. But it still let's me track what's happening with my patient and I've gone back to check details of something done or said multiple times

full_thread_text:
POST: Anyone else deal with this? 

We do many thousands of visits every year but nearly all are for home health. Recently began accepting cash pay patients. 

At first I was super stoked to just accept a VenMo payment outside of our business. 

But these patients are medically fragile and not without risk. The more I think about it, the more it feels like we need to run them through our business, including documenting every thing in our EMR. 

Am I correct in thinking we should be protecting the rest of our business by using our existing infrastructure for these cases?

COMMENT 1: I am all cash pay and do full documentation on all my clients. I am still responsible to them to fully assess their condition and provide intervention so I‚Äôm going to document it. 
I‚Äôm not doing the unnecessary check boxes that insurance co ask for but that‚Äôs is not the same as not documenting. 
I think we do our profession a disservice calling/treating wellness sessions as less/unskilled.

COMMENT 2: I always make a simple SOAP note in my EMR. Like someone said above, they're much shorter. But it still let's me track what's happening with my patient and I've gone back to check details of something done or said multiple times

post_text:
Anybody have a cancellation fee/policy? 

Most of my clients are very respectful of my time, however I currently have 2 that take advantage of me being ‚Äúlaid back‚Äù. 
How can I go about implementing this new policy with existing clients? What should I charge? 
Thanks in advance!

comments.text: My policy is if I can fill it, I don‚Äôt charge. If I can‚Äôt, I bill them. My intake form clearly states late cancellation will be billed, I let them know when calling to cancel that if I can fill it I won‚Äôt charge, but at the last minute it may not be possible. As I only see 4 a day it‚Äôs a 25% hit to my income and I share that info with them.

Depends on how far in advance they cancel.  Full cost of session if working a few hours. 50% if same day

Does your intake paperwork and consent form have a canceled policy

post_text: I've always offered complimentary discovery calls, but I'm going to hire an admin soon so I'll be shifting that responsibility to them. For other people who have made that transition, do you still call them discovery calls? I don't want to misrepresent anything and make patients think that they'll be speaking to the PT if they'll be on the phone with an admin, but I do want to keep the calls. I like to use them as a screening call to make sure they're appropriate for my practice and use them to review logistics ahead of time. Thanks for your thoughts!

comments.text:
How are you currently wording it on your site? Could you possibly switch to a booking link that blocks out when you‚Äôre treating but allows for scheduled calls when you‚Äôre free?

If you‚Äôre wording it as ‚Äúschedule free consult‚Äù or something similar I think you‚Äôd want it to be a therapist for at least the first part and then possibly transfer over to admin for the logistics piece.

Just a thought, that discovery phone call is a two way street. Clients are likely using it to determine if your personality, approaches, and expertise are a good match for them before they invest further. Personally, if I were going to seek out concierge style care (assuming you‚Äôre cash pay), I would want that person to spend a little time on the phone with me.  Just something to consider!

post_text:
1099 vs W2

I have a solo OT mobile practice and am wanting to bring on a COTA for some extra help. Currently it would be between 2-5 visits per week. They would have complete autonomy with scheduling and interventions completed during the visits. I‚Äôm wondering if I could pay someone higher rates and 1099 them or if W2 would be better for them? Thank you for any input - still trying to figure out the business side of all of this üòÖ

comments.text: The very nature of a OTA position requires W-2 given you are in a supervisory capacity as the OT and they cannot function autonomously.

W2 is the correct, legal way to go with this. There is a podcast that Nicole Cozean and her husband did on the difference between 1099 versus W2 but ultimately if they provider has a set schedule, they are W2.

full_thread_text:
POST: 1099 vs W2

I have a solo OT mobile practice and am wanting to bring on a COTA for some extra help. Currently it would be between 2-5 visits per week. They would have complete autonomy with scheduling and interventions completed during the visits. I‚Äôm wondering if I could pay someone higher rates and 1099 them or if W2 would be better for them? Thank you for any input - still trying to figure out the business side of all of this üòÖ

COMMENT 1: The very nature of a OTA position requires W-2 given you are in a supervisory capacity as the OT and they cannot function autonomously.

COMMENT 2: W2 is the correct, legal way to go with this. There is a podcast that Nicole Cozean and her husband did on the difference between 1099 versus W2 but ultimately if they provider has a set schedule, they are W2.

We‚Äôre looking for an amazing PT who‚Äôs passionate about truly *fixing people* ‚Äî not just managing symptoms.

**What we offer:**
üí™ **Elite Clinical Mentorship:** Learn the real secrets to helping patients heal fast and stay pain-free.
‚ù§Ô∏è **Patient-Centered Care:** Spend meaningful, uninterrupted time with each patient.
üí∞ **Competitive Pay:** You‚Äôre an expert ‚Äî you deserve to be paid like one.
üéâ **Fun, High-Energy Culture:** We love what we do and have a damn good time doing it. (If you‚Äôre low-energy or don‚Äôt enjoy people‚Ä¶ this probably isn‚Äôt your spot.)

If you‚Äôre hungry to grow, love helping people, and want to work with a driven, upbeat team ‚Äî let‚Äôs talk!

post_text:
Wondering if this is fair as an employee at an outpatient clinic? 

1. You are expected to ‚Äúmanage your caseload on your own time‚Äù, meaning you have to go over all of your patient‚Äôs insurance and scheduling eligibilities outside of work hours, which is audited. This can take up to 2 hours, you aren‚Äôt allowed to do this during work hours where you don‚Äôt have patients scheduled, but there aren‚Äôt any rules against doing this while treating pts, so that is what PTs might do to avoid taking work home. It‚Äôs stressful because every pt is given a survey periodically to rate each PT, and multitasking while treating pts risks lower ratings, and management only seems to care about negative feedback. Is it fair to have the PTs do this or should clinics typically hire enough administrative staff to address these duties? 

2. There is a ‚Äúproductivity %‚Äù that determines your work performance where any week there is a certain % of gaps in a PT‚Äôs schedule, management will put the blame on the PT. At times there are gaps because there is no patient available to come at that time, and for patients who don‚Äôt show up we often treat patients shared across different PTs so many times they aren‚Äôt even pts you usually see, or initial evaluations you‚Äôve never spoken to, or pts who simply don‚Äôt prioritize PT or their health. Management seems to stress more how much you can fill your schedule and interacting with pts in ways that will keep them as customers, and less on getting existing patients as best as they can faster. Is this fair to frame the work performance on how filled the schedule is, which isn‚Äôt completely within the PT‚Äôs control?

comments.text: If you‚Äôre doing all this on your own time instead of admin you might as well go solo!

Also, sounds illegal to be told to work on your own time. If you‚Äôre working for the company, then they should be paying you for the tasks. Never work off the clock, Ôøºunless you own your own business.

I reached out to a healthcare law firm about a month ago, to which they quickly scheduled me a consult call and I was happy to book with them. I paid the retainer fee on September 12, along with two inquiries in my email to get the ball rolling. I have not gotten any help since, now at almost a month after paying. I emailed them to let them know I was still waiting, to which they politely apologized stating that they‚Äôve been busy with hearings, and they would get back once they had a clearer picture of their timeline. That email response was over a week ago now and it‚Äôs holding my business back from growing to hire on more clinicians. 

All this to ask‚Äî is this normal??? While I respect their current clientele and trials to attend to, I am also a paid client and am losing out on money while I wait on them. I‚Äôve expressed this to them that my business has to be on hold until I can receive the contracts I‚Äôm asking of them. TIA!

comments.text: No not normal in my experience
Get your $ back and hire someone else

So I work under my business for a 1099 and then separately on my own business. Two patients from the 1099 (who weren‚Äôt on my caseload, I just did a one time visit with them before they left for the next two months) contacted me and wanted to work with me outside the 1099 since they didn‚Äôt like it or were confused with the tech people there. I bill medicare B on my insurance and they would be eligible under a kx modifier, but I‚Äôm not sure if this counts as like - stealing patients? They contacted me independently and I assume they have the right to choose their provider & I‚Äôm not taking any more patients from the 1099 since my caseload is increasing on my own company.

comments.text: What are the terms of your Employment Agreement for the 1099?
If the company loses revenue they had coming in due to you taking the patient they can sue you. I know someone who had a patient ask to go with them and got sued.

post_text:
I need a talk on being brave and quiting my job!

I already did last year, went down to PRN. It was all good until holidays. I was not enforcing healthy boundaries, patients were no showing, some insurances were not paying, and caseload went slightly low. I was feeling burnt out, did a few PRN sessions that were super easy and decided to go back 3 days a week. 

Now my private clinic is on fire. I am turning people away‚Ä¶ I need to resign AGAIN. I am overworking to meet HH patients on top of my regular clinic‚Ä¶ no lunch, dinner at 8 üòû I can‚Äôt keep this rhythm.

But I   I feel guilty because when I ‚Äúneeded‚Äù them they took me back, and now another PT (this one full time) just resigned.

I am not getting brave enough for another in person sit down with the director. Maybe an email, but I just am embarrassed of sitting down with her again and say‚Ä¶ so you know how 9mo ago you took me back‚Ä¶ well‚Ä¶ can we go back to PRN? üò¨üò¨üò¨üò¨

comments.text: The way I see it, if they are a great company that ‚Äútook you back‚Äù and genuinely look out for their employees, then they‚Äôll be happy for you that your business is booming and should be willing to work with you. If they ‚Äútook you back‚Äù because it was in their best interests and can‚Äôt be happy for you that you‚Äôre doing well, then why should you stress about it? Do what you need to do and take care of yourself.
They didn't take you back cuz they where nice, they needed you. Prolly in an area where there is a shortage of rehab. You call the shots for now

post_text:
Hello! I‚Äôm seeking advice regarding staffing and feedback. 
I‚Äôve been uncaged for 4 years. I am to the point I can afford a tech nearly 30-40 hours a week. I‚Äôve hired a tech who does an amazing job. He‚Äôs been with me for 9 months. He‚Äôs young, early 20s, has some technical school background, training for EMT. I do wound care. He assists w/patient care, scribing, ordering/stocking, cleaning, anything else needed. He‚Äôs very flexible and easy going. Very thorough and good at his job. After months of training, he is very familiar with our process, rarely needs corrected with work. Early on I had to correct him about professionalism (chewing tobacco and eating in front of patients), and he responded immediately and we haven‚Äôt had another issue. He has underlying anxiety (goes to counseling) so im careful giving feedback, but overall, he‚Äôs great!  About two weeks ago, I told him he didnt needed to stay late, but he chose to, then politely left mid treatment. Later he sent a text apologizing, saying he needed a break, he was getting burned out. We had 3 crazy evals that day, and when the pt dumped the colostomy bag, he was over it. Rightfully so. We also had 9 more evals than average that month (75% increase). It‚Äôs just the two of us. No front desk, so he was doing that too. A front desk person started this week. 

My issue is he has a habit of picking at his face. He will pick the scabs, look at them and flick them or throw them down. It‚Äôs all day. I am a freak about being clean, especially given what we do. He‚Äôs in every treatment w/me. About a month ago, he flicked it toward my treatment table (not on it) and I immediately addressed it after the treatment. I explained it would be good if he didn‚Äôt pick at his face as much and I explained my concern regarding the event that happened. He was apologetic and surprised when I pointed out his scab was directed at my treatment table, unintentionally of course. Unlike all of our other professionalism talks, not much changed except he doesnt flick them anymore. This week, as I was teaching him on my computer, he dropped a scab on my keyboard. He brushed it away. I was so upset by this, I didn‚Äôt say anything (which was best w/my personality). 

I feel I need to address this. My family doesn‚Äôt do this, so I dont really understand it. Im trying to decide how to approach this for the second time, assuming I should. I do not want to upset him. He does so much for our clinic. I‚Äôm concerned it‚Äôs a nervous habit and he‚Äôs going to have a hard time stopping. If I‚Äôm over reacting, I‚Äôm open to hear feedback. I know everyone is different. Maybe other people are like this and I don‚Äôt notice b/c Im not with them all day. Regardless, the feedback here has always been helpful. I‚Äôm open to all thoughts, opinions, and/or what you would do. Thank you in advance!

comments.text: Is he aware that he‚Äôs doing it or is it subconscious? I‚Äôd approach more with curiosity and a goal of helping him as this is a habit that would likely not be acceptable in most work places. Is he picking when he‚Äôs anxious? Overwhelmed? When he‚Äôs processing a lot of information? If the driving force behind the picking can be parsed out, it may be possible to reshape or replace the behavior.
One of my patients was diagnosed with this which was the first time I had ever heard of it. Dermatillomania

POST: Hello! I‚Äôm seeking advice regarding staffing and feedback. 
I‚Äôve been uncaged for 4 years. I am to the point I can afford a tech nearly 30-40 hours a week. I‚Äôve hired a tech who does an amazing job. He‚Äôs been with me for 9 months. He‚Äôs young, early 20s, has some technical school background, training for EMT. I do wound care. He assists w/patient care, scribing, ordering/stocking, cleaning, anything else needed. He‚Äôs very flexible and easy going. Very thorough and good at his job. After months of training, he is very familiar with our process, rarely needs corrected with work. Early on I had to correct him about professionalism (chewing tobacco and eating in front of patients), and he responded immediately and we haven‚Äôt had another issue. He has underlying anxiety (goes to counseling) so im careful giving feedback, but overall, he‚Äôs great!  About two weeks ago, I told him he didnt needed to stay late, but he chose to, then politely left mid treatment. Later he sent a text apologizing, saying he needed a break, he was getting burned out. We had 3 crazy evals that day, and when the pt dumped the colostomy bag, he was over it. Rightfully so. We also had 9 more evals than average that month (75% increase). It‚Äôs just the two of us. No front desk, so he was doing that too. A front desk person started this week. 

My issue is he has a habit of picking at his face. He will pick the scabs, look at them and flick them or throw them down. It‚Äôs all day. I am a freak about being clean, especially given what we do. He‚Äôs in every treatment w/me. About a month ago, he flicked it toward my treatment table (not on it) and I immediately addressed it after the treatment. I explained it would be good if he didn‚Äôt pick at his face as much and I explained my concern regarding the event that happened. He was apologetic and surprised when I pointed out his scab was directed at my treatment table, unintentionally of course. Unlike all of our other professionalism talks, not much changed except he doesnt flick them anymore. This week, as I was teaching him on my computer, he dropped a scab on my keyboard. He brushed it away. I was so upset by this, I didn‚Äôt say anything (which was best w/my personality). 

I feel I need to address this. My family doesn‚Äôt do this, so I dont really understand it. Im trying to decide how to approach this for the second time, assuming I should. I do not want to upset him. He does so much for our clinic. I‚Äôm concerned it‚Äôs a nervous habit and he‚Äôs going to have a hard time stopping. If I‚Äôm over reacting, I‚Äôm open to hear feedback. I know everyone is different. Maybe other people are like this and I don‚Äôt notice b/c Im not with them all day. Regardless, the feedback here has always been helpful. I‚Äôm open to all thoughts, opinions, and/or what you would do. Thank you in advance!

COMMENT 1: Is he aware that he‚Äôs doing it or is it subconscious? I‚Äôd approach more with curiosity and a goal of helping him as this is a habit that would likely not be acceptable in most work places. Is he picking when he‚Äôs anxious? Overwhelmed? When he‚Äôs processing a lot of information? If the driving force behind the picking can be parsed out, it may be possible to reshape or replace the behavior.

COMMENT 2: One of my patients was diagnosed with this which was the first time I had ever heard of it. Dermatillomania

post_text:
Has anyone transitioned into a Clinical Liaison position? I am a PT interviewing for one tomorrow for an inpatient rehab hospital and  looking to learn more about people‚Äôs experience. It strikes me as a role where you could be asked to do way too much for what you‚Äôre paid and cause higher burn out or turn over, but not sure. 

This job offers a base salary of 80-95k based on salary plus commission but I‚Äôm not sure how the commissions would work??

Would love to hear from others if they like the role, what they make, and how commissions work? Any red flags to look for or questions to ask in the interview tomorrow? 

Thanks!

comments.text: Is my experience , the Commission is  for the admission # you have over your monthly target #.  This role was a good learning experience for me but ultimately ended up being very poor work life balance. It depends on your company and the working structure and supports that are in place (eg : how are weekend/holiday referrals and admissions handled, how late in the evening do they accept admissions, how are team members vacations covered) and how often are they changing your monthly/yearly targets

I work as a clinical liaison. It‚Äôs very fast paced and your therapy knowledge will be a very small part of the role. Need to have a strong understanding of medical management, case management, insurance etc. Every facility is different as far as expectations. 

I would make sure to ask what your target would be for admissions, what referral sources you will cover, if you are allowed to work from home vs hybrid (as this will greatly affect your work life balance)

post_text: Looking for advice from those that have scaled a solo practice:  I currently have a solo cash based practice in one room   Average 25ish visits a week.  I have the opportunity to rent a larger space with 3 treatment rooms, better visibility and in the same strip mall Im currently in.  I enjoy the freedom I have not dealing with any co-workers.  But  I have concerns over long term viability if I don't expand and would like to build an asset.  I am considering hiring a part time PT (if I can find one) at 15-20 hours/week.  What are the pros and cons and other considerations I need to consider? TIA

comments.text:
In my opinion you have to at bare minimum grow to where you have at least 1 person underneath you solely for the reason of being able to take vacation and god forbid you get hurt or sick. The business has to cash flow while you‚Äôre out otherwise you just have risk. 

Starting part time is a great idea. I would make sure you have 3-6 months of payroll in the bank and an emergency fund prob 3 months of operating costs. I would also start building credit by establishing LOCs at various banks (do this while times are good because when you need it it‚Äôs hard to get). 

Once you have that established a part time hire is a great way to go. Just don‚Äôt bite off more than you can chew.

Have you thought about hiring a PTA instead? You can do evals and PNs and they do the treatments. See if you can legally bring them on as a contractor.

The biggest benefit to building a team is that you can take off time (sickness, kids soccer game etc.) while the company continues to run and patients still get seen. You can 
 make a lot more money. You can build a company that has value if you ever want or need to sell it.

Cons: a lot of new work, new learning, your no longer just a PT, you have to learn how to hire, train, lead,oversee etc. operations have to be decent, learn a lot of laws, learn payroll, HR etc etc etc.

It‚Äôs not for everyone, and while it is definitely the ‚Äúglamorous‚Äù position to be in, I wouldn‚Äôt recommend it if you are not fully in it. Sometimes you don‚Äôt know if you are built for it until you try it though. For me, I enjoy it but I don‚Äôt think I can do it forever.

There is no correct answer, you need to look at what you want to build and decide if you want to take on a new job that you have no experience in. What is the goal? How much do you want to grow? What do you want your life to look like? If you have a family, what are their thoughts with you taking on a new position filled with more frustration and challenges.

If you have any specific questions, I‚Äôd be more than happy to help out.

Ps. I purposely don‚Äôt proofread these kind of messages so that it comes out honest and raw, and not sugarcoated in any way.

post_text: Hi! I have been a PT x 20+ years. I am currenlty non-clinical and hear often from PTs who want to leave the profession. My future DIL is a senior in college and planning on going to PT school.  She is now considering PTA school due to debt/length of school.  We are meeting tomorrow to discuss.  Would love to hear from PTAs and or PTs who have any input. She loves personal training as well and plans to get her training certificate and start training clinets during her senior year. TIA!

comments.text: PT school has a very poor ROI these days. I was lucky and had minimal debt. I would do PA school if i were her

PTA here. Zero growth with the degree. I have made it a good career but watching my friends and co-workers advance through positions and corporate ranks and I am still ‚Äújust a PTA‚Äù 28 years later. I would have never made it solo financially in life if not marrying and my husband being the breadwinner. Nursing would be my choice if I did it all over again.

post_text: I own a mobile hybrid med B practice ( Healthy Aging Physical Therapy) - 16 providers (PT and OT) seeing around 900 visits/month for size and scale - and managing the new patient and eval process (between intakes, scheduling around estimated DC timelines, adjusting for changes in DC timelines, completing the VOBs and any addressing prior auth needs) is an absolute BEAR of a job. Ive built a pretty sophisticated spreadsheet system to manage it all, we‚Äôre on HENO for EMR, and use a Google form for our new patient registration to reduce the phone time required during the intakes.  I have an amazing 30 hour per week office manager who does the vast majority of it, but it is still overwhelming. I covered for her during her vacation this week and processed and booked 23 new evalsü§Æ booked between next week and into mid September. Everyone is at 100% capacity all of the time (knock on wood, I know these are good problems to have) - I Would love to hear any feedback from other similar sized practices how you manage it - any secrets to doing this more efficiently? How many admin staff / hours are typically needed to manage this much volume? We‚Äôre about to add two more FTE‚Äôs and im worried about our capacity to manage the additonal volume increase ..

comments.text:
First off. Amazingüëèüèªüëèüèªüëèüèª

You need to integrate go high level. It will help immensely. 

At those numbers are or now or considering a brick and mortar?  

We use Jane but our intake process rarely less than 4% of the time required anyone to be called or answer a phone.  New patients create a patient profile when they try to book  an appointment. It allows them to see the schedule. Choose the provider. Time. Services requested etc.  they upload their insurance. We require a credit card. It automatically send them the forms they need based on the visit type they choose etc.  

Then after the evaluation the therapist delivers the plan of care and schedules the full plan right then and there. It adds to commitment to the plan.    

If patients need to reschedule or change because of life. They can call in or go on their portal and change the visit on their own.  I promise you less and less people are going to call in each year.  2 years ago we had a 300% increase in online bookings. Having never spoke to anyone. This year we are at 437%.    Returning patients almost always use it unless they are 85+ and we are down to less than 6% of new to the practice patients that call in. Everyone else does it themselves. 

And you know what. 

Patients tell us how happy they are, how easy our system is and that they specifically chose is the first time because the other place the phone just rang and rang.

Hi Katie Wadland - we are similar.. started mobile and still have a team that does that next to a growing clinic base. 

We do roughly 800-900 visits a month.

I'm also on HENO and have a google spreadsheet empire - in particular for our onboarding process management 

We have partnered with rehab CEOs for years and out that have a nice flow in go high level CRM and also the guidance there across many clinics is generally 1 front office fte for every 110 visits or so.. so you're definitely pushing into 2nd front office hire territory. 

We also partnered with VA Rockstars - a PT specific virtual assistant staffing company.. because you're mostly mobile it sounds like and a lot of this being a discrete repeatable task - a VA could be a great way to get that hire done 

Lastly - I'm in a similar scenario as we grow and I'm looking at onboarding in and of itself as a discrete phase or 'project' - with that I'm looking at project management software solutions ... Things like Asana, motion, Trello or Monday - I'm still sorting out if this is the move myself

And you know what. 

Patients tell us how happy they are, how easy our system is and that they specifically chose is the first time because the other place the phone just rang and rang.

COMMENT 2: Hi Katie Wadland - we are similar.. started mobile and still have a team that does that next to a growing clinic base. 

We do roughly 800-900 visits a month.

I'm also on HENO and have a google spreadsheet empire - in particular for our onboarding process management 

We have partnered with rehab CEOs for years and out that have a nice flow in go high level CRM and also the guidance there across many clinics is generally 1 front office fte for every 110 visits or so.. so you're definitely pushing into 2nd front office hire territory. 

We also partnered with VA Rockstars - a PT specific virtual assistant staffing company.. because you're mostly mobile it sounds like and a lot of this being a discrete repeatable task - a VA could be a great way to get that hire done 

Lastly - I'm in a similar scenario as we grow and I'm looking at onboarding in and of itself as a discrete phase or 'project' - with that I'm looking at project management software solutions ... Things like Asana, motion, Trello or Monday - I'm still sorting out if this is the move myself

post_text: How do you guys hire/find new PT's? I live in a smaller town, close to a huge city, about an hour away. But If I could, I could hire 4-5 more PT's based on how busy we are. But It is so hard to find anyone right now. I've done job fairs but that's more long term Investing In hiring someone.

comments.text: Do you take students?  That might be a nice way to train and recruit future therapists get awareness for your practice.

When recruiting therapists, no matter where, active recruiting is a must. 

So not just posting a job and hoping/waiting for applicants. Getting a licensure list from your state which usually will include emails (and hopefully phone numbers), emailing, texting, calling to those is the zip codes close to you. 

Posting on social media/linkedIn. 

Get in touch with the local PT schools in your area and try and connect with those last year PT students. 

Differentiating your job when you post it. Highlight the reasons someone would want to work for you. Also don‚Äôt list every duty/the entire job description in the post. It‚Äôs not necessary and no one reads it. 

It‚Äôs so important to get back to applicants the same day and set up an interview asap. Then make a decision quickly.

full_thread_text:

COMMENT 1: Do you take students?  That might be a nice way to train and recruit future therapists get awareness for your practice.

COMMENT 2: When recruiting therapists, no matter where, active recruiting is a must. 

So not just posting a job and hoping/waiting for applicants. Getting a licensure list from your state which usually will include emails (and hopefully phone numbers), emailing, texting, calling to those is the zip codes close to you. 

Posting on social media/linkedIn. 

Get in touch with the local PT schools in your area and try and connect with those last year PT students. 

Differentiating your job when you post it. Highlight the reasons someone would want to work for you. Also don‚Äôt list every duty/the entire job description in the post. It‚Äôs not necessary and no one reads it. 

It‚Äôs so important to get back to applicants the same day and set up an interview asap. Then make a decision quickly.

post_text: Hi everyone. I have a question regarding PTA supervision.  I just started a job that is super busy. I work with 2 PTA‚Äôs . Each of them see at least 20 patients a day on a 11-12 hour day, while I see at least 10-12 patients mostly evals and re- exams ( yes I know this is crazy!!). My question is : is there a maximum number of patients as a supervising PT to co sign?

comments.text: In Nebraska the limit is 2 PTAs per PT but no limit on visits seen.
I think this varies by state. Your practice act may have more clear guidance. In Texas, a PT can supervise as many PTAs as they feel they can adequately supervise (no patient limits)

COMMENT 1: In Nebraska the limit is 2 PTAs per PT but no limit on visits seen.

COMMENT 2: I think this varies by state. Your practice act may have more clear guidance. In Texas, a PT can supervise as many PTAs as they feel they can adequately supervise (no patient limits)

*If you have any advice or personal experience please private message me*

If my W2 employer is willing to hire me as a 1099 contractor (through my LLC) - is that a slam dunk or would there be a reason not to? 

I‚Äôve asked this before on here and half immediately said heck yes and half responded with ‚Äúwell actually they can‚Äôt just do that‚Äù‚Ä¶.. 

They can. They‚Äôve hired another PT though their LLC/SCorp and they‚Äôre reaping the benefits (New work truck, writing off vacations, deducting portions of the mortgage/utilities/etc). 

SO‚Ä¶ My question is do any of you have any first hand experience with this? Could any of you recommend a financial advisor/CPA that could help me? 

I‚Äôd love to work with someone that could lay out everything for me, weighing the Pros and Cons (PTO/benefits/savings/etc) vs (higher income, deductions, etc). Like if I were to go 1099, I know you‚Äôre supposed to ask for much more money hourly bc they‚Äôre no longer having to cover your benefits‚Ä¶ I need to find someone that knows how to tread that line. TIA! 

TLDR: I have an important decision to make regarding my current job - and I‚Äôm not sure if I should just ask for more money (salary) or even consider 1099 for the tax benefits.

comments.text: Bumping hoping that someone with a referral sees this

Someone would need to know your current benefits package.  i.e. PTO, con- ed, holidays, retirement, your projected health insurance costs if u cover it yourself vs what u pay now. Etc.  It's not that easy to get u the answer.  But knowing all of these answers, it shouldn't be too difficult to come up with a price point to leave.

post_text:
I just had somebody apply for a position and stated that she eventually wants to pursue her own practice that she previously started but isn‚Äôt in a position to grow it right now. She‚Äôs great, interested and aligns with my company‚Äôs mission but my worry is that she would build a caseload under my company and then take them to her own practice eventually. We are a fast growing multidisciplinary practice and she would be the first of her specialty 
Is there anything to do? Should I pursue or avoid?

comments.text:
Slightly different opinion because I've been in business in a small town now for almost 15 years in two different clinics that I've owned.
The old me would operate in fear and say not to hire her because she might hurt your business later... However, the new me who's been through this before both positively and negatively would advise this: 
IF she truly fits your mission, your culture, and can help you grow your business now, hire her. Mentor her as an entrepreneur. Teach her business on purpose. If she offers a specialty that you don't have currently, let her bring it to your clinic and build rapport with the community. 
If or when she leaves eventually, help her be successful and she'll do the same for you in return. Think of this as a partnership opportunity instead of a competition. Maintain her respect for you and when she leaves, that respect will remain and she may refer to you for people who don't fit her mold. Anyone who leaves with her is not your ideal client anyway. 

I actually developed a Direct Pay Mentorship Program with the intention of bringing in staff to build my practice, mentoring/training them to run their own practice, and then I offer an opportunity to stay or to leave to start their own. They may stay after seeing what running a business actually "costs" in time, money, and sacrifice.
I live in rural Appalachia... We don't have a high population or a great socioeconomic status, but there are still plenty of clients to go around. When you are mentoring someone who is driven, it helps BOTH of you. They will generate referrals for you while they are with you because they desire to be successful. They will push your business forward and make you better if they are the right fit... And you have ensured that the community has options for great care, whether it's you or not. 
At the end of the day, she may stay or she may go, but you can make it a positive experience for both of you if you approach it from a different perspective... 
I hope this helps!

They told you up front.Good sign of integrity. A shady person looking to snatch business likely would not have.

I would hire and maintain good communication along the way. When/if she wants to break away from you and do her own thing make sure there is a mutual understanding of expectations.

The reality is some people will follow her even without her solicitation. That‚Äôs showbiz.

We‚Äôre in the people business, you build relationships, provide care for people, and people build bonds with providers/patients they spend time with. These bonds will cross company lines, and that‚Äôs ok.

Plenty of business to be had.

post_text: I‚Äôm an OT in a school setting and am contracted for 190 days a year. I‚Äôm openning a private OT practice. My contract states, ‚ÄúThe employee agrees not to engage in any business activity that directly competes with or solicits business away from the core services provided by the AEA during the term of this agreement.‚Äù  The AEA (my employer) does not provide outpatient OT services. Is it that simple or should I be worried? Do I need to do anything to cover myself? Please help!

comments.text: It should be fine as long as you don‚Äôt let any of the parents know that you offer outpatient services. That could be seen as ethical using one job to drum up business for the other.

If they don't offer outpatient OT services and then you DO offer outpatient OT services, that seems as simple as can be. But don't take my word for it. I was literally fired on those grounds a few years ago ü§£

full_thread_text:
POST: I‚Äôm an OT in a school setting and am contracted for 190 days a year. I‚Äôm openning a private OT practice. My contract states, ‚ÄúThe employee agrees not to engage in any business activity that directly competes with or solicits business away from the core services provided by the AEA during the term of this agreement.‚Äù  The AEA (my employer) does not provide outpatient OT services. Is it that simple or should I be worried? Do I need to do anything to cover myself? Please help!

COMMENT 1: It should be fine as long as you don‚Äôt let any of the parents know that you offer outpatient services. That could be seen as ethical using one job to drum up business for the other.

COMMENT 2: If they don't offer outpatient OT services and then you DO offer outpatient OT services, that seems as simple as can be. But don't take my word for it. I was literally fired on those grounds a few years ago ü§£

post_text:
Help me understand something!
I have 8 1099's who are treated as such. I am bringing on a W2. I know this means I need to get WC insurance (in Maryland) but I'm confused on the need for group malpractice. My 1099s each have their own malpractice and general liability, and I also have my own. My practice is "additional insured" on each policy. 

Can the W2 get his own and then I reimburse him as "accountable plan" to avoid him being taxed on the reimbursement?

comments.text:
No.  W2 all need to be under your policy.  Even if they had their own private policy. That would not legally excuse you from having them under yours.  

Curious why everyone else a 1099 and then take on a W2?

post_text:
I offer personal training as well as physical therapy for my
business. Should I document my personal training sessions?

comments.text:
While not legally required to, I document a visit happened, and 2-3 sentences of what happened. 

Usually any major data points I have invented for the client: 30 min walking distance, weight vest laps around living environment, time to do complete 50 sit to stands, etc 

Main reason I do this is to be a better trainer and remember benchmarks as well as tax purposes to deduct driven miles for each session.

When I did personal training, I had a simple chart with all the exercises down the side and dates across the top. In each column, I recorded weight, #reps, time under load. Ôøº at the very bottom of the column, you could write any significant notes (like where you focused on technique, tolerance, etc.).  This way you have a record and are tracking progress easily. Ôøº

post_text:
For those whose staff are paid per treatment (rather than part time/ full time), how many gaps per day/ week/ etc do your staff get paid for.  Do you use a flat number for the day/ week or is it based on total treatments? Just looking for different ways different clinics handle this. 
Thank you!

comments.text:
I've worked as a 1099 contractor as an employee straight commission (50%+). 

I've never been paid for gaps, except when a client late cancels and the employer collects payment anyway. 

However, an employer who desires to retain employees would make every effort to eliminate long gaps and to keep the schedule full. 

I also appreciate not being required to be in the office when I have no clients on the books.

There are some employers who pay an hourly rate for admin/cleaning/etc when  therr are no appointments scheduled.
I worked as a contractor and was paid per patient an hourly rate. For the wellness patient there was a 60/40 split. I only got paid if I was seeing a patient.

full_thread_text:
POST: For those whose staff are paid per treatment (rather than part time/ full time), how many gaps per day/ week/ etc do your staff get paid for.  Do you use a flat number for the day/ week or is it based on total treatments? Just looking for different ways different clinics handle this. 
Thank you!

COMMENT 1: I've worked as a 1099 contractor as an employee straight commission (50%+). 

I've never been paid for gaps, except when a client late cancels and the employer collects payment anyway. 

However, an employer who desires to retain employees would make every effort to eliminate long gaps and to keep the schedule full. 

I also appreciate not being required to be in the office when I have no clients on the books.

There are some employers who pay an hourly rate for admin/cleaning/etc when  therr are no appointments scheduled.

COMMENT 2: I worked as a contractor and was paid per patient an hourly rate. For the wellness patient there was a 60/40 split. I only got paid if I was seeing a patient.

post_text:
Hi everyone. For anyone that went uncaged and has employees. How do you handle benefits? Specifically in NY. We‚Äôre a small agency and I‚Äôm trying to build a team of like minded therapists. I know this is going to sound crazy, but it‚Äôs not about getting rich. I honestlytly working on creating an agency thats morw like a family- where we value work/life balance. Happy therapists make for happy clients.
I do have a W2 (SLP) and a few 1099s (billing person and therapists who have full time jobs and are looking for a few extra sessions a week). I‚Äôd like to add more w2s but can‚Äôt compete with big agency benefits. Things like maternity leave and health insurance are hard to cover when you‚Äôre just a tiny rural agency. I do offer money towards insurance every week, paid billing/notes, and mileage, as well as Fridays off.  But if I paid maternity, I would essentially be using my own pay (I have a full caseload) to pay for the 6 week paid maternity for my employee. I can‚Äôt afford to do that and it‚Äôs been a deal breaker for some potential employees. Any advice on this would be appreciated!

comments.text: I honestly think a lot of companies mislead their employees. A PT I interviewed said her company gives 8 weeks full paid maternity. I‚Äôve never heard of any company doing this. It would be great if they did, but I don‚Äôt think anyone could/does.
Short term disability can cover maternity leave. Check out Sun life

post_text:
Sharing a shining example of how to hand off a discussion with a client lead to another member of your team: 

"Only thing I will deal with is the pricing and payment.  He will cover everything else for youüòä.  He's real good at what he does.  I trust him completely in my absence"

Had this sent to me from the wedding DJ I'd been primarily communicating with. He turned me over to his colleague, and I was seriously encouraged by how he did it.

Made me confident that this wasn't some new person on the team he didn't trust to do the job alone yet.

Could logic have led me to that same conclusion if he hadn't expressed his full confidence in this individual? Maybe. 

But when the person on the other end places high importance on the decision, there's a lot of emotion involved, too. Don't bet their trust in you.

post_text: I recently hired 3 PTAs, which was very exciting. Two have been great. 1 is showing concerning behavior. She is lying her head down and napping in the clinic when she does not have patients while other therapists are treating. She will sit for 2-3 hours and not pitch in to clean the clinic if she does not have patients scheduled. We have a policy of no overtime unless approved yet she is the only therapists that goes into overtime. I was just told by another therapist that she fell alsleep while treating a patient. And the one day I left before her this week she stayed clocked in to get paid additional time when her patient left the clinic 25 minutes prior and the front desk said she "disappeared" for that time and waited to clock out late. How do you handle this? We just had a meeting last week on what therapists should do during down time, making sure therapist are clocking out on time, etc?

comments.text: Document incidents, talk to the PT and set up clear objections to correct the behavior (if you want her to stick around ü§î) and check that she‚Äôs doing it. If she is in the probationary period and you don‚Äôt want her to stick around, fire her.
Tell her bye

post_text:
**AW RITE! AW RITE! AW RITE!**

It's the First Friday of 2025!

Let's *KICK IT UP A NOTCH!!* ü•≥

First, I want to acknowledge that I've been a little absent the past two weeks.  

Lesson: It's OK to not GO-GO-GO allllll the tiiiiime.  

That being said, today's list might be a little shorter than usual. 

But let's give ourselves some grace.  It was the Holidays!!

I hope you all enjoyed them!

Here we go....

Someone posted a couple of days ago if it really was viable to start a cash based practice.  Let's roll the tape on UNCAGED PATHWAY student, Matt Davis.  He is 7 months into the program and he just hired his SECOND person (one is a trainer, the new hire is a PT)! WAY TO KICK IT UP, MATT!! LET'S GOOOOO!!

Perseverance and trusting the process.  That's what Jessica Kerr did in 2024.  The result? In 2023 her practice, Allied Therapy Partners saw 138 patients.  That number jumped in 2024 to 914 patients served!! KICKING IT UP A NOTCH!!!

Also growing her practice, **NeuroAxis Rehabilitation Services**, is Kelsey Harris!  This Beast of Western PA is hiring both PT and OT to add to her already amazing team!!

Matt Bonander grew his Famousity AND his practice!  He appeared in the local *The Cross Timbers Gazette* about his practice, **Focused Care PT**, opening a new location! CONGRATS!

Also growing a big dose of Famousity was Jeremy Sutton! He appeared on a KSLA News 12 (Shreveport - Bossier City, LA) segment talking about the second edition of his book, *Neck Pain Solutions*! But, WAIT! THERE's MORE!  Jeremy appeared on the show a week or so earlier talking about ***Senior Day*** - a day that he founded where he treats senior citizens in the area to gifts, etc.! This physical therapy owner of **Healthy SBC** is going places!!

This MAY have been announced a while back, but Ashley Tunquist is going to be expecting her 1st baby in about 2-4 weeks!! 

Lots of people are growing, and I love it!! Eric Otero is growing his team at **Pinnacle Movement and Performance **in Delray, FL, and his looking to hire a PT!! LET'S GOOO!

In the Austin, TX area? My man, Stephen Dunn, is looking for a unique therapist to work in his manual therapy, Pilates, and Gyrotonic clinic!  

Shana Yap Townsend is a proud momma.  Her son, Jack, earned his Communications degree from San Jose State University!

Jackie Raymond DeLuca is riding high going into 2025. She got married!! CONGRATS!!!

Speaking of babies.... CONGRATS to Michelina Richardson Baker who welcomed her little man, Archer Michael, into the world!

Remember, unless you change something - a habit, a behavior, etc., then this New Year will be just another year! LET'S GROW in 2025!!

Make it a *fantawesome* weekend, everyone!

I'm excited to get back in the saddle!

comments.text: Thanks boss!
Hahahaha! I wanna see you in a saddle! üòÇüòÇüòÇ

post_text: Have a new PT, and we have our 3 month meeting today. What kinds of things do you guys like to go over during meetings like those?

comments.text:
New grad, or new to you? 
This may not apply depending on your setup, but my first jobs were in chaos. Discuss stress/load management. Make sure they are happy and not taking a bunch of work or stress home. If your employee is happy at work, and has good work/life balance, they will stick around and continue to work hard. 
If they aren‚Äôt meeting certain expectations, I would discuss that after asking how they are doing.

Interesting, the first ever Doctorate of Athletic training program with Physical Therapist leading the program. 2 year program only. This program projects that DAT‚Äôs (Doctorate of Athetic Training ) will make the same amount as a PT. Everyone is infringing on everyone‚Äôs practice.

comments.text:
Yup‚Ä¶ Blurred lines isn‚Äôt doing any of us a favor. 

They still aren‚Äôt rehab professionals but I‚Äôm worried that with this kind of degree they will think they that they are. 
 
I work in professional sports and I‚Äôm washed out by ATCs. Sports teams not understanding why these injuries are happening in the first place nor how to properly rehab them. I mean it‚Äôs kind of great for me because people realize my work is so much different than what they are getting at facility. And the teams notice it too as I get referrals from the team medical staff. 

While I advocate for everyone to stay in their scope of practice this just highlights how we should be a multidisciplinary approach not one discipline doing all the therapies. That isn‚Äôt evidence based. We should be learning how to include us all on sports teams‚Ä¶ including me, an occupational therapist. Arguably the first OT in the NFL.

If you follow this kind of stuff you‚Äôll def be seeing me more. I‚Äôm a bulldog about it. Shaking things up a bit. I won‚Äôt be everyone‚Äôs favorite because of it but I‚Äôm ok with that. History wasn‚Äôt made by people being proper and polite.

post_text: Hiring vs finding a minority partner‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm at the stage where I am thinking about hiring but at the same time I feel like if someone has part ownership they will likely to work harder for it. Plus, after being uncaged, I would like to encourage others to do the same. Anyone want to share what they have done or would do differently?

comments.text:
I would recommend never ever taking on a partner. I've seen too many nightmare breakups. 

There are many other options including  simply co-marketing or partnering with her business to share clients/virtual assistants/etc. 

Or, just hire another therapist.
Hire someone for minimum wage plus a phantom equity deal, good compromise between an employee and a partner.

post_text:
Not strictly in line with this groups motive, but I was hoping to get some feedback! I am set to potentially move up within my company‚Äôs structure from assistant director to director as our current director/regional partner is moving to a different clinic. I‚Äôm meeting with the president and CEO this week. 

How might you advise structuring this conversation? I don‚Äôt want to outright ask for the silver spoon/raise but I don‚Äôt want to be told to ‚Äúearn it/prove it‚Äù without any objective goals/benchmarks or timelines to achieve. Advice?!

comments.text: How many staff will you be over? Not sure the size of you company but if it‚Äôs over multiple clinics and 20+ clinicians then it‚Äôs likely you are competing against other managers and external candidates. Seek to solve their problems and show how you have delivered in the past. If it‚Äôs just a clinic manager role then yeah you likely have no competition or minimal competition. People move states for regional jobs at big companies

Ask about the KPIs going to director. You're equally wondering if it's a good fit for you/your life as they will equally need to fill the role. With a title change like that and added/changed responsibilities there is an expectation of a raise. If the raise or lack thereof (if I'm reading your post right) doesn't align to the increased load it should be a no for you and they will now be required to hire, train, move someone (takes time and money). 

You are in a great position here (not them) remember that.

full_thread_text:

I am set to potentially move up within my company‚Äôs structure from assistant director to director as our current director/regional partner is moving to a different clinic. How might you advise structuring this conversation? I don‚Äôt want to outright ask for the silver spoon/raise but I don‚Äôt want to be told to ‚Äúearn it/prove it‚Äù without any objective goals/benchmarks or timelines to achieve. Advice?!

COMMENT 1: How many staff will you be over? Not sure the size of you company but if it‚Äôs over multiple clinics and 20+ clinicians then it‚Äôs likely you are competing against other managers and external candidates. Seek to solve their problems and show how you have delivered in the past. If it‚Äôs just a clinic manager role then yeah you likely have no competition or minimal competition. People move states for regional jobs at big companies

COMMENT 2: Ask about the KPIs going to director. You're equally wondering if it's a good fit for you/your life as they will equally need to fill the role. With a title change like that and added/changed responsibilities there is an expectation of a raise. If the raise or lack thereof (if I'm reading your post right) doesn't align to the increased load it should be a no for you and they will now be required to hire, train, move someone (takes time and money). 

You are in a great position here (not them) remember that.

I hired a new grad who found out last night that she failed her licensure exam.  She has already moved to Charlotte so she could start working here as soon as she got her license.  I can‚Äôt really hire her full time until she can start seeing patients except for a few things such as putting together workshops, shockwave, etc.
Do any of you have things she can do remotely to help you out to earn some money?  She will re-test in January.

comments.text:
Unfortunately, I don‚Äôt have work for her. I just wanted to say that you‚Äôre demonstrating the type of leadership we need in corporate America!  While you‚Äôre not obligated to find her temporary work, you are assisting her with it.  I wish more employers cared about their people like this. 

I wish her good luck on the exam!
I made way more money waitressing evenings & studying for the exam during the day when I was a new grad compared to when I worked as an aide for the experience/resume builder.

post_text:
Hiring Immediately PTA position.

Location : Bensalem/Levittown, PA.

**Qualifications :**

The position requires ensuring every patient receives a unique experience through a comprehensive, thorough, and customized physical therapy regimen with an emphasis on quality care provided in a friendly and encouraging environment.

Experience in Outpatient settings.

Physical Therapist Assistants must be licensed, or license eligible in the state of PA.

**Responsibilities :**

Clinical structure allows professionals to operate at the top of their license

Become a part of the next generation of clinical leaders through training, CEUs, professional development, and leadership training

As a PTA you will be responsible for assisting in the treatment and progression of patients.

The overall treatment of patients will include following a plan of care for patients and ongoing treatment with patients through all phases of physical therapy

Physical Therapist Assistant will continually utilize professional communication skills and a team approach.

Document patient‚Äôs progress on weekly progress note in an accurate and timely fashion, and obtain the co-signature of the PT.

Ensure MD orders are obtained for treatments, recertifications and discharges.

**Benefits :**

In addition to a competitive compensation package with an incentive plan and all the benefits you'd expect such as paid time off, employee assistance, etc.) you will also enjoy:

Structured mentorship to grow to management position.

No cost live and online CEUs.

Reimbursement of license fees.

**Requirements :**

Licensed in PA.

Motivated and energetic.

Minimum 1 yrs of Outpatient Clinic experience preferred.

NEW GRAD's are also welcomed.

Have to travel between the Levittown and Bensalem locations, 7 miles apart.

Fulltime / Part-time position available.

Salary : $30-$32 / hr.

Other benefits : Medical Insurance, life Insurance, paid time off.

Email your resume to : contact@physiomove.us

post_text: I'm hiring my first contract employee. I'm a single member LLc but for tax purposes, and S corp.  What things do I need to consider in doing this? I have an employee contract, way to do payroll.  Do I need to add her to my liability insurance??  But I assume she carries her own too?  She will get a percentage of the visit plus the surcharge for the travel will be hers.  Is she responsible for her own equipment?  She will use my EMR... What else am I missing?  Thank you!!!

comments.text:
Congratulations on hiring your first contractor! Here‚Äôs a rundown of essential considerations:

1. Independent Contractor Classification: Make sure she meets the requirements for a 1099 contractor, not a W-2 employee. This means she should have flexibility in how and when she works, supply some of her own equipment, and take on some business risks (like travel expenses).

2. Insurance: Yes, you‚Äôll want her to carry her own liability insurance. It‚Äôs still a good idea to confirm this with your own insurer, as they might require you to list contractors for full coverage. Having clear documentation of her liability coverage can help protect both of you.

3. Contract Specifics: Make sure your contract covers:

Payment Terms: Outline the percentage per visit, any reimbursement for travel, and payment timelines.

Confidentiality and HIPAA Compliance: Since she‚Äôs using your EMR, include specific language about HIPAA compliance and patient data security.

Non-compete or Non-solicitation Clauses: Decide if you want any limitations around her working with your clients independently.

4. EMR Access and Compliance: Ensure she‚Äôs trained on your EMR and understands your documentation standards. Since she‚Äôs using your system, emphasize that she adheres to the same security measures you do.

5. Equipment: If she‚Äôs responsible for her own equipment, be clear about what is needed to fulfill the job (e.g., laptop, mobile device, therapy tools) and ensure this is in writing. Anything you provide would technically be taxable, so it‚Äôs easier for her to provide her own if she can.

6. Payroll and Taxes: If she's a 1099 contractor, you won‚Äôt withhold taxes for her, but make sure to issue her a 1099-NEC at the end of the year for tax purposes. Keep detailed payment records to help her accurately report her income.

7. Worker‚Äôs Compensation: While 1099 contractors typically aren‚Äôt covered by worker‚Äôs comp, it‚Äôs worth checking your state‚Äôs requirements, as some have specific regulations for certain industries.

8. Clear Communication: Especially with your first hire, be proactive in setting up regular check-ins to make sure everything is running smoothly. A strong onboarding process will help set clear expectations and keep the working relationship positive.

Starting with these steps will help lay a solid foundation for both of you!

I hired two people this year, one W2 and one independent. Their rolls for employment are very different. For W2, I have a number of associated costs (disability, liability, payroll taxes, mileage stipend, health insurance, etc). My independent contractor has none of those associated costs/benefits. She is paid a flat fee for service/per session rate vs my w2 who is hourly. Independent carries her own insurance and pays her own taxes on what she receives. States and fed is VERY specific about differentiating between the two. Carefully do your research and decide what role you want your new hire to have. And be specific.  The contract you have this person sign should state what type of hire they are.

Thank you for letting me share this post.  It is because of this group that we have grown so much.  

We are hiring a full time Pelvic Health Physical Therapist to work in a mobile PT setting within North and West City of Chicago and nearby suburbs. This is a great opportunity to serve a perinatal population that truly needs in-home services.

Allied Therapy Partners is a practice that values work-life balance, professional and personal development and flexibility. We offer a competitive salary with bonuses, mentoring (if needed), health insurance, dental insurance, 401k, PTO, sick time, paid holidays and mileage reimbursement among other perks.

We are a therapist-owned and run company and we provide mobile pelvic health services and birth preparation services in our patient homes. We believe in the one-on-one care model and offer 1 hour sessions. If you or someone you know is interested in applying or getting more information, please send questions and/or resume and cover letter to info@alliedtherapypartners.com.

Learn more about us on our website at www.alliedtherapypartners.com or read our 5 star reviews on Google; our patients love us and that really speaks for the practice.

post_text: Hi yall! I am looking to hire instructors to teach yoga and Pilates in my studio as an add on service. Any advice on how to structure pay or what to include in a contract? They would be 1099 employees. Do I need to add them to my insurance or require them to have their own?

comments.text:
Half of my practice is a yoga studio. All of my instructors are 1099s. We do a 60(then)/40 (me) split with a minimum payment per class. So, if they only have one person in class they don‚Äôt just make 60% of $12. 
I require them to each hold their own insurance. 

The main thing I have in my Independent contractor contract (aside from what services will be rendered for what pay) is that all yoga students are considered to belong to the studio/practice and if they provide yoga to them outside of the studio, that it‚Äôs grounds to terminate the contract.

I require them to each hold their own insurance. 

The main thing I have in my Independent contractor contract (aside from what services will be rendered for what pay) is that all yoga students are considered to belong to the studio/practice and if they provide yoga to them outside of the studio, that it‚Äôs grounds to terminate the contract.

post_text:
Just some PSAs for y'all.

- Stay active in your local groups. Especially ones where people are frequently connecting with each other ("who do you use for hair/nails/doctor/dentist/PT/gym/personal training").

- Connect with people who are doing things like what you do. They will advocate for you! AND now you know people to refer out to when you're not the right fit.

- Plan WAYYYYY in advance for who to hire and how to hire. I just got 6 new evals because of one connection, and it's going to swamp my schedule. And I am not prepared to hire -- learn from my mistake. ü´†

Keep on truckin', y'all.

post_text: Hi Everyone! For anyone familiar with Florida regulations, does Florida require general or direct supervision of PTA's in Outpatient Mobile Therapy? I know Medicare does until the Proposed Rule change, but I'm thinking moreso for selfpay clients. The statues are very confusing in the way it's worded, and under what chapter PT in Private Practice falls under. Appreciate any insight - thank you!

comments.text: I work PRN for a company that does insurance based or self pay outpatient home therapy and I supervise PTAs working in the same county or surrounding just by cosigning for their notes so general is fine.  I believe the term is being in the same geographic area. I do evals and progress notes either via video call on doxy or by traveling to see the patient.
I believe it means that they are available at all times by phone / in general area . It allows PT to physically be in an alternate building

full_thread_text:

COMMENT 1: I work PRN for a company that does insurance based or self pay outpatient home therapy and I supervise PTAs working in the same county or surrounding just by cosigning for their notes so general is fine.  I believe the term is being in the same geographic area. I do evals and progress notes either via video call on doxy or by traveling to see the patient.

COMMENT 2: I believe it means that they are available at all times by phone / in general area . It allows PT to physically be in an alternate building
