post_text: When did you know you were able to switch from offering a 1099 position to an hourly W-2 or salaried position? I‚Äôm scheduling an appt with my accountant but wanted to hear from people in practices. I have a 1099 clinician that is at about 20 direct contact hours. SLP practice. Thanks.

comments.text: Agreeing with what everyone said about misclassification.  1099 = you do not dictate their schedule, you do not provide them with any tools or equipment, you do not mandate a dress code, etc.  In other words, they provide you a service.  Think of it as hiring the repairman.  You hire him to do "x" job but he comes when he can, brings his own tools and wears what he wants.  Anything else is a W2.  W2= if you dictate their work hours or schedule, you provide them with equipment and you tell them to wear scrubs.  *hope that helps

From talking to a lawyer here in CO many people are misclassified as ‚Äú1099‚Äù that really are W2 employees. Have you looked at the requirements for classification for both categories? Or consulted with an attorney?

full_thread_text:
POST: When did you know you were able to switch from offering a 1099 position to an hourly W-2 or salaried position? I‚Äôm scheduling an appt with my accountant but wanted to hear from people in practices. I have a 1099 clinician that is at about 20 direct contact hours. SLP practice. Thanks.

COMMENT 1: Agreeing with what everyone said about misclassification.  1099 = you do not dictate their schedule, you do not provide them with any tools or equipment, you do not mandate a dress code, etc.  In other words, they provide you a service.  Think of it as hiring the repairman.  You hire him to do "x" job but he comes when he can, brings his own tools and wears what he wants.  Anything else is a W2.  W2= if you dictate their work hours or schedule, you provide them with equipment and you tell them to wear scrubs.  *hope that helps

COMMENT 2: From talking to a lawyer here in CO many people are misclassified as ‚Äú1099‚Äù that really are W2 employees. Have you looked at the requirements for classification for both categories? Or consulted with an attorney?

post_text: I am contemplating hiring a PT to provide coverage during my vacation. Should I classify them as a PRN employee or an independent contractor (1099)? What other factors should I consider in this decision?

comments.text: I believe you're in CA...we can't hire 1099 due to Assembly Bill 5 (the Uber rule) unless it is a business to business. Probably a good time to network with another business in the area that you can pay a flat rate per session. Otherwise you could hire a PRN employee
If you are just hiring for your specific vacation period a 1099 might be appropriate. If you are going to use PRN for other times etc I would consider PRN employee.

full_thread_text:
POST: I am contemplating hiring a PT to provide coverage during my vacation. Should I classify them as a PRN employee or an independent contractor (1099)? What other factors should I consider in this decision?

COMMENT 1: I believe you're in CA...we can't hire 1099 due to Assembly Bill 5 (the Uber rule) unless it is a business to business. Probably a good time to network with another business in the area that you can pay a flat rate per session. Otherwise you could hire a PRN employee

COMMENT 2: If you are just hiring for your specific vacation period a 1099 might be appropriate. If you are going to use PRN for other times etc I would consider PRN employee.

post_text:
I have a brick and mortar business. About 1/2 cash and 1/2 Medicare. 14 sessions pay my basic bills. 20, my ‚Äúbooked‚Äù number pays taxes, vacation time, emergency fund, continued education fund‚Ä¶ 
I‚Äôve been working home health 3 days a week (18 units, which I share between 4 days), and been averaging 11-13 sessions a week for the last couple weeks. And then I suddenly got 5 initial evaluations next week. 3 Medicare, 2 cash. 2 are posture/scoliosis based (which I usually do 2 to 3 times a week at first to obtain best results)‚Ä¶ All word of mouth. Zero marketing. At most a social media post a week. People just like my results.
in addition, 1 former patient is returning for new problems. I expect to be booked at 20 for next at least 4-5 weeks‚Ä¶ with likely waitlist. 
I am ok keeping 20 + 18 units of HH for a month or 2, but not much longer. I also need to give 4 weeks notice at HH to cash my PTO.
So question is, at what point it is ‚Äúsafe‚Äù to call it quit on the HH side?
I am scared of calling it on HH and then suddenly go back to 12 sessions a week in a few months

comments.text: If you're really worried stay on with home health but as a PRN employee or an independent contractor. You don't want to sacrifice your business for home health and it sounds like you have some really good opportunities. Plus word of mouth is huge! It's how I get a lot of my returning patients

Great job! You are clearly doing an amazing job! I would go atleast another 90 days with your HH and Brick and mortar and then resign with the 4 week notice from HH. Worse case scenario you switch to prn with HH and or sign up with another prn company in the event you‚Äôre unable to fill your brick and mortar caseload.

full_thread_text:
POST: I have a brick and mortar business. About 1/2 cash and 1/2 Medicare. 14 sessions pay my basic bills. 20, my ‚Äúbooked‚Äù number pays taxes, vacation time, emergency fund, continued education fund‚Ä¶ 
I‚Äôve been working home health 3 days a week (18 units, which I share between 4 days), and been averaging 11-13 sessions a week for the last couple weeks. And then I suddenly got 5 initial evaluations next week. 3 Medicare, 2 cash. 2 are posture/scoliosis based (which I usually do 2 to 3 times a week at first to obtain best results)‚Ä¶ All word of mouth. Zero marketing. At most a social media post a week. People just like my results.
in addition, 1 former patient is returning for new problems. I expect to be booked at 20 for next at least 4-5 weeks‚Ä¶ with likely waitlist. 
I am ok keeping 20 + 18 units of HH for a month or 2, but not much longer. I also need to give 4 weeks notice at HH to cash my PTO.
So question is, at what point it is ‚Äúsafe‚Äù to call it quit on the HH side?
I am scared of calling it on HH and then suddenly go back to 12 sessions a week in a few months

COMMENT 1: If you're really worried stay on with home health but as a PRN employee or an independent contractor. You don't want to sacrifice your business for home health and it sounds like you have some really good opportunities. Plus word of mouth is huge! It's how I get a lot of my returning patients

COMMENT 2: Great job! You are clearly doing an amazing job! I would go atleast another 90 days with your HH and Brick and mortar and then resign with the 4 week notice from HH. Worse case scenario you switch to prn with HH and or sign up with another prn company in the event you‚Äôre unable to fill your brick and mortar caseload.

If you have employees, how many hours per week are you treating? I have 1 full time, 2 part times and 1 PRN who covers for vacation

Anyone else feeling guilty that they‚Äôre not treating as much? Im treating about 8 hours per week. I feel like I spend a lot of time doing admin/marketing/big picture vision things. I‚Äôm not always busy but my days are somehow full regardless. My goal has always been to gradually moving to working on the business, but still feel pretty guilty for not treating at least part time.

comments.text: Do not feel guilty!  You have to step out if you are going to do what's best for your employees and patients.  To build better things for them it is you duty to treat less.  If you do not you're doing you patients and team a disservice üíØ

Do you feel guilty or do you miss it? If you like the admin and are profitable, do what you want. Your job is to run the business and pay your employees. If you miss it, can you delegate some of the predictable tasks to someone else so you can treat more?

- get your new hire an additional account under your EMR.

I‚Äôm looking to hire someone for my mobile practice. I‚Äôd like to hire a part time front office person and a part time clinician.

I have no idea where to start. Already talked to my accountant, so that‚Äôs fine. I have no idea what I need to do, legally, I guess.

Can someone give me some pointers?
full_thread_text:
POST: I‚Äôm looking to hire someone for my mobile practice. I‚Äôd like to hire a part time front office person and a part time clinician.

I have no idea where to start. Already talked to my accountant, so that‚Äôs fine. I have no idea what I need to do, legally, I guess.

Can someone give me some pointers?

post_text: I‚Äôm a solo practioner SLP with a very full schedule (currently at 50-55 sessions a week). I was going to hire in a PT on to my team, but have no idea how people afford to hire. I have contracts with set rates and negotiating those rates isn‚Äôt an option (peds). Her current agency offers PTO, insurance, Sick time, retirement, mileage, paid time for notes/meetings. They even offer 12 weeks paid maternity. I feel so defeated. To offer those things, you need to have a substantial amount of employees all making money for you. I don‚Äôt have that. How can I possibly grow without going bankrupt? Finding therapists in my area is nearly impossible so it seems they can name their price. I want to expand my team, offer more services, (PT, OT), but fiscally and logistically, it just seems impossible.

comments.text: I‚Äôm in somewhat of a similar dilemma, but I‚Äôm trying to think outside the box on hiring. What would drive you to work for your company? There are a good number of disgruntled PT employees out there who would probably love to be ‚Äúuncaged‚Äù but for one of a number of reasons don‚Äôt take that leap. Could you offer maybe a backbone for them to grow a practice within your practice? Give them more ownership on their portion while still covering your cost to bring them in? Just thinking out loud. DM me if you want to throw ideas off each other
Welcome to why so many large healthcare companies sold themselves to private equity.

post_text:
If my currently employer is willing to hire me through my LLC (so I‚Äôll stay but also still be able to get all the tax benefits) - that‚Äôs a slam dunk yes, right? *In Tennessee by the way*

I make ~125k/year as a salary employer and would be giving up PTO and a 3% max match simple IRA plan BUT I‚Äôm sure you all know the benefits of being a business owner. 

I created my LLC last year but after having a kid 4 months ago, haven‚Äôt been able to do any ‚Äúside work‚Äù after my 9-5, so I haven‚Äôt even tried using any tax benefits since it‚Äôs not drawing in income. 

I see this as a way to continue having a simple 9-5 job, get the tax benefits, and not have to stress about TRULY being a business owner‚Ä¶. Also I really need a new truck ü§£

*I do know that they save money with not having to pay benefits, but they made it sound minuscule. I had planned on asking for $5/hr more, should I aim higher? My benefits cost me $50 per pay period at the moment.

**I am the DOR and run 9 clinics - hours would never be a concern.

Last edit: I got this idea after a PT told me that he had a HH company hire him through his LLC and he writes off vehicles, utilities, dinners, an ‚Äúoffice‚Äù space in his home, etc. But based off this thread, idk if that‚Äôs legal.

comments.text:
Getting patients isn‚Äôt the hard part of business owning. You‚Äôd have to be just as compliant as a 1099 contract. Especially to actually classify as a true 1099. Contractors do not get benefits. Also, questionable if you can have decision making power in your role inside the company and constitute as a 1099. 

You would be responsible for your own WC insurance, malpractice, and other insurances. You would still have to file business paperwork annually. You‚Äôd still have to have accounting software. I‚Äôm honestly not seeing the benefit of maintaining your LLC.

Having you as an independent contractor with a 1099 is a huge tax benefit for your employer, but it can screw you at tax season because you end up having to pay half the taxes that they would pay 100% of if you were a W2 employee.

post_text: Good morning, my fianc√© and I are travel physical therapists and are considering starting to run a mobile practice while we are on the go. The one thing that has us stumped right now is health insurance as we would no longer be getting benefits through our travel companies. Any recommendations or resources on the best and most affordable marketplace insurance plans? Thank you in advance and I hope you all have a wonderful day striving towards financial freedom!

comments.text: Marketplace is based on your state of residence because states can do whatever they want with those plans they can sell them at cost or they can jack the price up and pocket the change. Every state has different laws regarding short term plans some don‚Äôt offer them at all and some states like Iowa allows. You to have them up to three years and they are pretty good deals. You can always consider a health Cost sharing plan and supplement it with a policy like Aflac hospitalization,accident and injury. All state dependent. I am an agent and a PT.

I always wonder if they are cataustrophic only and if they cover what we do when we are the patient.  

My first OT director made changes happen for the entire hospital employees‚Äô insurance because there was no OT coverage  (circa 1993) yet they staffed OT!?!?

Can you imagine being a PT/OT/ST and not having coverage that we fight for every day?

post_text: I own an in home personal training business for seniors in which I provide therapy inspired exercises (private pay). I‚Äôm ready to hire and need any help/advice I can get on hiring a 1099 employee. I‚Äôve gathered that they need to fill out an agreement, a non compete, and a w9 form. Anything else? Also, should I write up the agreement or do I need a lawyer to do so? Any other other advice is welcome!

comments.text:
Before you move ahead, please understand that a '1099' is a form you issue to any contractor for whom you paid more than $600/year so they can report it on their taxes. (This law is if you're in the USA)

If you're looking for an employee, it's not the same as a '1099'.

By the sounds of what you're looking to do, you probably cannot have independent contractors because the workers will be an integral part of your business.

Here's a blog post that might help understand about the difference between ICs and employees. 

(Ask me how I know!)ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

https://www.irenediamond.com/are-you-an-really-ic-or-employee

As a current 1099 employee, I wouldn‚Äôt sign anything with a non compete. My feeling as an independent contractor is I should be able to work for whoever, whenever I want. If you want me to sign a non compete than make me a W2 employee so I don‚Äôt get killed in taxes and give me benefits.

Also, should I write up the agreement or do I need a lawyer to do so? Any other other advice is welcome!

COMMENT 1: Before you move ahead, please understand that a '1099' is a form you issue to any contractor for whom you paid more than $600/year so they can report it on their taxes. (This law is if you're in the USA)

If you're looking for an employee, it's not the same as a '1099'.

By the sounds of what you're looking to do, you probably cannot have independent contractors because the workers will be an integral part of your business.

(Ask me how I know!)ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

https://www.irenediamond.com/are-you-an-really-ic-or-employee

COMMENT 2: As a current 1099 employee, I wouldn‚Äôt sign anything with a non compete. My feeling as an independent contractor is I should be able to work for whoever, whenever I want. If you want me to sign a non compete than make me a W2 employee so I don‚Äôt get killed in taxes and give me benefits.

post_text: Received a job offer to be a home health OT as an independent contractor, which I have not been before. This company typically provides aide and nursing services, and is just starting up providing therapies. of course I would be having my own liability insurance, but what would be the other risks involved with signing on to a company that is so new to offering therapies? Feeling a little overwhelmed and hesitant to sign the contract

comments.text:
Risks would include them limiting how many visits you could do or ending the contract when they are unsuccessful at implementing the knew program. Make sure they are paying you enough if you are 1099. You should be getting 20% more as a 1099 compared to w2. Also, use it as am opportunity to build your business. Make sure they will let you hire COTAs through your business which is contracted with them so they can do some of your visits for you. Then go out and find more contracts like that. 
Oh and make sure they contract your LLC, not you directly. 
Shoot me a message if you want to discuss it further.

post_text: Help!  I am a new mobile provider and have been open a few months.  I recently hired a PTA as a contractor from another company I had worked for.  I know they did a background check on him but I did not do one myself and do not have a copy of that one.  I just got a call from an ALF where he has seen a few people for me and they report that he has made inappropriate sexual comments to several people there including residents and a staff member.  None so far that I know of were our patients.  I am just not sure how to handle this.  Of course I won't be using him anymore and he will not be allowed back in that building.  What is my liability here?  I am not sure how to handle this and how much info I can or should give out to the building administrator.

comments.text: Glad you are firing him. I‚Äôm not sure about liability but if you wanted to make a difference there. I would show up myself and treat those patients until you find another therapist.

I learned a lesson from a situation similar to this is you should have a background check even on your contract therapists as well as they should have their own liability insurance that you have a copy of their certificate. So that way if anything come up you can provide your insurance with that information.

full_thread_text:

I just got a call from an ALF where he has seen a few people for me and they report that he has made inappropriate sexual comments to several people there including residents and a staff member.  None so far that I know of were our patients.  I am just not sure how to handle this.  Of course I won't be using him anymore and he will not be allowed back in that building.  What is my liability here?  I am not sure how to handle this and how much info I can or should give out to the building administrator.

COMMENT 1: Glad you are firing him. I‚Äôm not sure about liability but if you wanted to make a difference there. I would show up myself and treat those patients until you find another therapist.

COMMENT 2: I learned a lesson from a situation similar to this is you should have a background check even on your contract therapists as well as they should have their own liability insurance that you have a copy of their certificate. So that way if anything come up you can provide your insurance with that information.

Any tips/tricks on convincing someone to hire you as an independent contractor (through your own LLC)?

Wanting to call around to several Home Health agencies asking if they‚Äôd hire a PRN DPT and would love to use my LLC so I can start using the tax benefits. Thanks in advance!

comments.text: I told them they don't have to pay my liability insurance nor the other half of employment taxes and they were good with those ideas. Then I get to reap the tax benefits with deductions.

I did this! I did a Google job search for HH agencies near me who were hiring. Then I created an email and attachment to explain my business and that it's available to contract. It worked and I contract with a HH agency. They already had contracts in place, so I didn't have to worry about creating one.

post_text: If I hire a PTA for prn work, and they make their own schedule, etc, can they ever be considered a 1099? Or would they have to be a W2 as they require supervision from a PT?

comments.text: I have PTAs as 1099. They make their own schedule and have the ability to decline patients. The supervision from a PT portion is a licensure requirement but doesn't mean you are telling the PTA exactly what to do and when.

I think it will really depend on how you set it up and possibly your state. I have a couple friends who were audited here and Utah and got fines. Could be an Utah thing. Could be how they set it up. I have all my PTAs as W2 just to avoid that problem.

full_thread_text:
POST: If I hire a PTA for prn work, and they make their own schedule, etc, can they ever be considered a 1099? Or would they have to be a W2 as they require supervision from a PT?

COMMENT 1: I have PTAs as 1099. They make their own schedule and have the ability to decline patients. The supervision from a PT portion is a licensure requirement but doesn't mean you are telling the PTA exactly what to do and when.

COMMENT 2: I think it will really depend on how you set it up and possibly your state. I have a couple friends who were audited here and Utah and got fines. Could be an Utah thing. Could be how they set it up. I have all my PTAs as W2 just to avoid that problem.

post_text:
For those who are mobile with team members? How do you foster a sense of belonging and collaboration? 
We have team and education meetings, outings etc., but it‚Äôs not the same when people get to see each other everyday in the clinic and build friendships as well as having meaningful conversations about treatment ideas.

comments.text: We are nearly 100% a virtual team (2 engineers go in office‚Ä¶) and we utilize a few techniques to foster close working relationships. 1) Slack as a communication tool for quick questions, comments, funny moments in your day, etc. You can have separate channels for ‚Äúfunny things people said‚Äù, ‚Äúlearning moments‚Äù or ‚Äúclinical questions‚Äù etc. 2) You can offer an open weekly or bi-weekly ‚Äúoffice hours‚Äù on Zoom where the leadership/manager is available on Zoom, say from 4-5pm while therapists are documenting. Everyone can be working on their tasks but it‚Äôs nice to foster question/answer sessions or have a little conversation.

full_thread_text:

We have team and education meetings, outings etc., but it‚Äôs not the same when people get to see each other everyday in the clinic and build friendships as well as having meaningful conversations about treatment ideas.

COMMENT 1: We are nearly 100% a virtual team (2 engineers go in office‚Ä¶) and we utilize a few techniques to foster close working relationships. 1) Slack as a communication tool for quick questions, comments, funny moments in your day, etc. You can have separate channels for ‚Äúfunny things people said‚Äù, ‚Äúlearning moments‚Äù or ‚Äúclinical questions‚Äù etc. 2) You can offer an open weekly or bi-weekly ‚Äúoffice hours‚Äù on Zoom where the leadership/manager is available on Zoom, say from 4-5pm while therapists are documenting. Everyone can be working on their tasks but it‚Äôs nice to foster question/answer sessions or have a little conversation.

post_text:
I'm doing some research on potentially hiring my first PT here in California. It seems like according to CA law, PTs can't be classified as independent contractors. Is this correct? **Have any practice owners in CA hired therapists as independent contractors?** I wanted to hire independent contractors and have them function as PRNs, i.e. setting their own hours and choosing who they want to see. But I need to make sure it's legally sound to bring them on as 1099s instead of W2s.

(The law I'm referring to is AB5 and became effective in January 2020)

Thank you!

comments.text:
Cannot 1099 in CA under most circumstances.  

Can if it‚Äôs something you do not usually or customarily offer. 
But go W9 it‚Äôs essentially the same thing.  So bring on a PT that has incorporated themselves and you‚Äôre good.   They assume their own liability and risk and insurance etc.  but at that point you become a staffing agency so to speak.
I did a lot of research on this too before I hired my first PT in CA, and everything I found pointed to making them a W2 employee. Hope this helps!

full_thread_text:
POST: I'm doing some research on potentially hiring my first PT here in California. It seems like according to CA law, PTs can't be classified as independent contractors. Is this correct? **Have any practice owners in CA hired therapists as independent contractors?** I wanted to hire independent contractors and have them function as PRNs, i.e. setting their own hours and choosing who they want to see. But I need to make sure it's legally sound to bring them on as 1099s instead of W2s.

(The law I'm referring to is AB5 and became effective in January 2020)

Thank you!

COMMENT 1: Cannot 1099 in CA under most circumstances.  

Can if it‚Äôs something you do not usually or customarily offer. 
But go W9 it‚Äôs essentially the same thing.  So bring on a PT that has incorporated themselves and you‚Äôre good.   They assume their own liability and risk and insurance etc.  but at that point you become a staffing agency so to speak.

COMMENT 2: I did a lot of research on this too before I hired my first PT in CA, and everything I found pointed to making them a W2 employee. Hope this helps!

post_text:
Hypermobility + running expertise?  
Do you have advice on building tension/elasticity in floppy tissues?  Available for telehealth?

Goal:  Utilize running as part of my training plan for Grand Canyon Rim-Rim-Rim (4 days with daypack) in June 2024.

Background: 
I have mild EDS and continually hurt myself running.   
I ran track & cross country in high school, but haven‚Äôt been able to run as an adult.  I‚Äôm 41.
I‚Äôm great with vertical strength ‚Äî Olympic weightlifting 4 days a week is my primary exercise. 
I can hike 5-8 miles with a backpack no problem. 15-22 miles with trekking poles.  
I do advanced level Pole dancing with minimal injury 1-2 days a week. 

BUT running is elusive.  

What I‚Äôm already doing:
‚Äî Soleus & Gastroc strengthening.  Some anterior tib. 
‚Äî Loading the forefoot/toes while strength training.  
* it was all going well until last week when I had a posterior Tib flare on the right & the talus jammed up on the left.  #feelingfrustrated 
‚Äî I use the Toe Pro and Mobo board inconsistently to work medial/lateral stability.  *Lateral and rotational stability likely needs more attention. 

Barriers:  Lack of a plan & knowledge of specific variables to optimize my training.  Feedback & problem-solving support.  Accountability.  ADHD + too many hobbies.

comments.text: I‚Äôm hypermobile and I run! I have found success with isometrics, particularly hips/glutes. Running with a metronome can help with over-striding‚Äîwhen you‚Äôre floppy it‚Äôs easy to over-stride, and this can place more load on the distal musculature on impact. A metronome can help you maintain a cadence and keep some co-contraction of agonists/antagonists (particularly the hips) to keep a more stable proximal base. I use a cadence of somewhere between 160-180 bpm, there are playlists on Spotify that particularly cater to these bpm‚Äôs. Hope this helps!

I don‚Äôt have any advice about running, but I did a hiking R2R a few years ago in September when I was 45 (2 nights at Phantom Ranch so only carried a day pack.)  My 2 cents- the time I put in going up and down the stadium stairs at my local high school wearing my loaded pack that summer was the most beneficial training I did. If you haven‚Äôt joined them already, there are R2R and R2R2R fb groups that offer lots of great advice for first-timers. Good luck with your training and enjoy the canyon- there are definitely moments when you need to ‚Äúembrace the suck‚Äù but it is an amazing experience üòä

post_text: Looking to sign with a home health company per diem in NW Ohio and they offered $85 a visit. Is that good? Should they reimburse for gas mileage while per diem and doing multiple patients per time? What else should I negotiate or ask? Thanks!

comments.text: I'm in northeast Ohio and that rate sounds pretty good based on what I've heard. I like the points system better to weight visits bc while 85 is pretty solid for follow up visits, if you do many opens, it gets unreasonable pretty fast. Mileage compensation should be expected, and the IRS sets that rate. Another concern when you are per diem is if the company can actually keep you busy enough to create the salary you want.
Are you going to be an employee or working as a 1099 Independent Contractor?

full_thread_text:
POST: Looking to sign with a home health company per diem in NW Ohio and they offered $85 a visit. Is that good? Should they reimburse for gas mileage while per diem and doing multiple patients per time? What else should I negotiate or ask? Thanks!

COMMENT 1: I'm in northeast Ohio and that rate sounds pretty good based on what I've heard. I like the points system better to weight visits bc while 85 is pretty solid for follow up visits, if you do many opens, it gets unreasonable pretty fast. Mileage compensation should be expected, and the IRS sets that rate. Another concern when you are per diem is if the company can actually keep you busy enough to create the salary you want.

COMMENT 2: Are you going to be an employee or working as a 1099 Independent Contractor?

post_text:
Hello all. 

Looking for PTs in Detroit Michigan. 

I saw this post on one of FB groups. This woman is in her 50s and started lifting not too long ago. She said she had not so great experience with the previous PT. Hopefully this one will be much better!

Here is her post: 
"Some background & specs: 52, 5‚Äô6‚Äù, 130lbs. (This is the genetic body type of both sides of my family).  Type 2 Diabetes. Very sensitive to carbs and trying to manage blood sugar & menopause without medication & through fitness as much as I can (not against other options). History of frozen shoulder (completely healed at this point) and chiropractic issues that are manageable and come less frequently now. 

I‚Äôve been working with a fitness trainer (male) who seems to ‚Äúget it‚Äù and is open.  I have a chiropractor (male) who I‚Äôve seen on and off for over 20 years. Has helped a lot and I respect his knowledge.  The book ‚ÄúNext Level‚Äù has inspired almost all the lifestyle changes I‚Äôve made.  I was not an ‚Äúathlete‚Äù before this book.  Very stagnant life before. Very weak. 

Began weight training in March 2023 after a 2month recovery from a slip n fall & minor car accident.  As of last week, I squat 95lbs and about 15-20lbs for most arm bb. (Still learning all the gym language.) my focus is to maintain a healthy fat/muscle ratio to manage blood sugar & train to manage menopause.  I feel great! Blood sugar down from 10 A1C to 7 A1C (hoping to get it lower). Very few menopause symptoms.  Still really carb sensitive so I don‚Äôt get all my carbs in daily, increased fat but not doing Keto. Shared my current macros. They are going up gradually to accommodate my blood sugar.  

(Feel free to offer any suggestions) 

My issue: last week I was doing pushups and pulled something in my neck.  Was having some same side lower back/hip pain during hinge exercises, too.  Saw the chiropractor who fixed the issue and said the following ‚ÄúWith your posture and frame you should lift lighter with more reps(üôÑ). Don‚Äôt lift over head.  Do exercises that keep your chest open. Women over 50 are at higher risk for shoulder injury during weight training.‚Äù (Admittedly, was hoping for, you look great, posture is stronger‚Ä¶kudos, kudos, kudos)

I‚Äôm finding myself comparing all I‚Äôve learned and experienced since picking up ‚ÄúNext Level.‚Äù Wanting to consider all the respected perspectives.  I know I have a long way to go. I‚Äôm still deciphering Dr. Stacy Sims recommendations and applying. 

I respect everyone‚Äôs experience and perspective here.  Hoping for information, perspective and inspiration that will keep me motivated and moving forward.  (Don‚Äôt worry, Ill take everything offered in context of it being FB) Thanks."

Any takers?

comments.text: Melanie Eplin is in Detroit, I believe

Can't think of anyone offhand, but I really hope someone helps her cement better narratives into her brain than what that chiro had to offer her!!

Someone help this go-getter continue to get after it.

post_text:
For those with employees: do you have requirement for outside of treatment engagement in the practice? For example: social media post, workshops, presentations etc? 
What does that structure look like for your practice?

comments.text: Double check current laws- it was illegal for business to require employees to post or share anything on social media. Employees don‚Äôt even have to have their picture on a business website without their specific consent.

If I have them do anything outside patient treatment, I make sure I pay them their hourly wage. For context, I have a mobile practice and pay my employees per visit.

Anything you ask your employees to do, make sure you put yourself in their shoes. You are now in the business of serving your employees more than your patients.

full_thread_text:
POST: For those with employees: do you have requirement for outside of treatment engagement in the practice? For example: social media post, workshops, presentations etc? 
What does that structure look like for your practice?

COMMENT 1: Double check current laws- it was illegal for business to require employees to post or share anything on social media. Employees don‚Äôt even have to have their picture on a business website without their specific consent.

COMMENT 2: If I have them do anything outside patient treatment, I make sure I pay them their hourly wage. For context, I have a mobile practice and pay my employees per visit.

Anything you ask your employees to do, make sure you put yourself in their shoes. You are now in the business of serving your employees more than your patients.

post_text: As a business owner, what do I need to do on the federal & state level when a W2 employee quits?

comments.text:
I don‚Äôt think you need to do much just account for it in your workers comp audit. 

Most importantly get a letter of resignation from the employee so they can‚Äôt try and claim unemployment against you.

full_thread_text:
POST: As a business owner, what do I need to do on the federal & state level when a W2 employee quits?

COMMENT 1: I don‚Äôt think you need to do much just account for it in your workers comp audit. 

Most importantly get a letter of resignation from the employee so they can‚Äôt try and claim unemployment against you.

post_text: I recently started a mobile OP practice. Right now it‚Äôs just me but I have always planned to add additional therapists later on. I will be going on maternity leave for 3-4 months in late January or early February. Short term disability that covered maternity leave was not an option for me as an individual. I do of course want to spend time bonding with my baby and healing but some income would be nice too. Other solo practitioner moms who have done this: did you hire a PRN or FT/PT employee to cover your maternity leave? If so, how did you as the business owner handle chasing down referrals, POC and recert signatures, insurance payments, etc.?

comments.text: Would love to see the feedback on this as I‚Äôm due in December. I feel like I was just starting to gain some traction with my practice and now I‚Äôm afraid to take on patients that I might not be able to see through their entire episode of care

i just did this. my babe is 3 months. i opted not to hire anyone/have anyone cover. i was down to about 6 patients the week of my due date. they were all incredibly understanding. i lost a couple patients that i had hoped to pick back up when i returned (slowly) at 9 weeks post partum. but it's ok. i'm building back up.

post_text:
Second post, sorry y‚Äôall! 
Do you offer any paternity leave? We haven‚Äôt had to deal with any maternity and paternity yet, but as our clinicians are starting to grow their families this question has come up a few times. I know ultimately it‚Äôs our decision on what we do, but just seeing what other companies are doing/offering. Thanks!

comments.text:
I‚Äôve never (17 yrs as a PT) worked for a company that offered paid parental leave, just STD + PTO or unpaid leave. I‚Äôve always resented that. My husband isn‚Äôt in healthcare and gets 3wk 100% paid leave.. his company breaks it down that both parents get 3wk for ‚Äúfamily bonding‚Äù and this can be used for any situation - adoption, birth, etc. The birthing person gets an additional 9wk paid leave for ‚Äúphysical recovery‚Äù, so 12 wk total for them. 

Paid leave is the right thing to do for both parents, and (sadly) offering this would set you apart from the rest of the healthcare field. I know you‚Äôre probably a small company, and it really should be the big orgs that are doing this, but if you can, please offer it!

I think it‚Äôs hard for any employer to do this, but my personal opinion is that at least partially covering paid parental leave is the right thing to do and you‚Äôll have a more loyal staff because of it. Family first.

COMMENT 1: I‚Äôve never (17 yrs as a PT) worked for a company that offered paid parental leave, just STD + PTO or unpaid leave. I‚Äôve always resented that. My husband isn‚Äôt in healthcare and gets 3wk 100% paid leave.. his company breaks it down that both parents get 3wk for ‚Äúfamily bonding‚Äù and this can be used for any situation - adoption, birth, etc. The birthing person gets an additional 9wk paid leave for ‚Äúphysical recovery‚Äù, so 12 wk total for them. 

Paid leave is the right thing to do for both parents, and (sadly) offering this would set you apart from the rest of the healthcare field. I know you‚Äôre probably a small company, and it really should be the big orgs that are doing this, but if you can, please offer it!

COMMENT 2: I think it‚Äôs hard for any employer to do this, but my personal opinion is that at least partially covering paid parental leave is the right thing to do and you‚Äôll have a more loyal staff because of it. Family first.

post_text: Business owners - More is not always better. Better is better.

comments.text: Truth

And to piggy back off that conversation we had about it, better is different for each business. I look at it like air. Air in itself isn‚Äôt good or bad but is dependent upon the circumstance. Air to survive‚Ä¶extremely good and vital. Air to a fire‚Ä¶more destruction. 

Better depends on both your short and long term goals. And like we talked about before, comparison is the devils tactics. Better for what I need could be detrimental to someone else if they are using better as a comparison.

full_thread_text:

COMMENT 1: Truth

COMMENT 2: And to piggy back off that conversation we had about it, better is different for each business. I look at it like air. Air in itself isn‚Äôt good or bad but is dependent upon the circumstance. Air to survive‚Ä¶extremely good and vital. Air to a fire‚Ä¶more destruction.

post_text:
Hello! Wondering if I can get a little insight from those that are mobile cash PTs with W2 employees. 

I have been in practice for just over a year and a half in Wisconsin as a mobile PT and am going to hire in January. I'm hiring someone with 9 years of experience and am looking for recommendations for good packages?

Debating between hourly and salary? Certain dollar amount that is fair/competitive? Benefits? (Thinking SEP IRA with matching contributions at certain time points with retention and certain dollar amount for CEUs annually). She does not need health benefits. Thinking maybe bonuses for surpassing or meeting productivity standards or incentivizing referrals she generates with a great dollar value. Too many ideas and not sure where to start.

Thank you!

comments.text: Don't hesitate to ask her what she is looking for.  Your ideas above are great ideas with regards to benefits.  Whichever pay structure you choose (hourly vs salary) - and there isn't necessarily a "right one or a "wrong one" because this could change as she grows; the more important thing is you identify the expectations you have of her.

#WI #Employees - Suggest contacting State of WI and understand requirements for employees...... I came across my written notes (from several phone calls) 13 years ago.... and reminisced about how much time (and errors) it saved when setting up WI LLC, and understanding obligations for WC, retirement requirements, employees, ( 1 employee v. 1+ and different req.) etc.

post_text:
Debating on hiring my first PT/potentially OT 

1099 vs W2 (in FL) 
I‚Äôm a bit torn about this. I understand the main difference and the tax liability and offering benefits with W2. 
However, it makes me a little bit nervous to hire a 1099 because I want some control over what they do. I feel like I‚Äôve worked very hard to build my company and my reputation in the way I treat patients/family and don‚Äôt want to have no control over my contractor.

Any thoughts on W2 part time or PRN without benefits? 

For biz with multiple disciplines, how did you learn about documentation and billing for other disciplines as well as rules and regulations? I‚Äôm considering bringing on an OT in August.

comments.text:
Something to keep in mind is that ANY hire is an investment.  You hire for these reasons:
üëâ The hire gives YOU time back
üëâ The hire fills a need 
üëâ The hire allows you to make more money

True, you have extremely limited ‚Äúcontrol‚Äù over a 1099; however, consider the possibility of bringing on someone as a 1099 with the goal / incentive of them moving into a W2 position.

Han Nguyen you'll have absolute control over your contractor. Not happy with what they do? Stop giving them patients. They will sign a contract with you and should understand expectations. You can require a 30 day and a 90 day (or whatever time frame) employee assessment.

post_text:
Hey all!

Looking for some advice/creative solutions. 
I left my job in March to pursue my own practice/escape the burnout and get my life in order. I am primarily doing cash concierge ortho/personal training but, I do have a small location that I can practice out of.  A few things happened at the beginning that have made this current venture not sustainable or, not headed in the direction of the dream, without serious overhaul. 

My mentor/past professor is opening up a clinic inside a brand new fighter‚Äôs gym and would like me to run it. Initially I would be the only PT but as we expand I will move into the clinical director role. I don‚Äôt have specifics yet but this is someone I trust who is building a package for me to make me an offer ‚Äútoo good to refuse‚Äù (high salary, benefits, revenue sharing) 

Since working for myself I have noticed that the ‚Äúperk‚Äù I value the most is the freedom/flexibility of schedule. It has allowed me to stay on top of my personal appointments, manage the home, take better care of my dog and enjoy life. Going back to a 9-5 (probably more with the admin side) is where I will have the most trouble adjusting‚Ä¶ Looking for creative options/perks/benefits that I could suggest in order to make the work life balance more balanced! I‚Äôm willing to compromise on pay or other benefits if it enables a more ‚Äúfree‚Äù life. 

Thanks in advance for any suggestions or ideas!

comments.text:
I would ask what the goal metrics are and what the professor is bringing to the table...do they already have referral sources ready to give you patients? How busy will you need to be in order to have all the great perks/pay? Ask how many visits that person is expecting you to see/when would another clinician be brought on? Once you know numbers, you'll know how busy each day you'll end up being and then you can see how the work life balance will be.

Side thought, if you already have your own business but struggling with getting it going, why not partner with this person instead of being an employee?? Or contract with this person? Once you are an employee, your control of your day is gone.

Bargain in control? 1-2 set admin days where you don't treat and can be work from home? Schedule your MD visits a few weeks in advance,and just be allowed to move your schedule around to accommodate? May be harder at the beginning when it's just you. Not easy necessarily but if that's what matters to you, then find a way to make it work

post_text: Looking for some sound tax advice regarding a nanny. I run a mobile pelvic floor physical therapy practice. I have a nanny 15 hours a week. She helps clean and organize my PT equipment, and does laundry used in my PT visits. My son is still at 2 naps a day so she has no issue doing this while he‚Äôs napping. My question is-can I W2 her as a household employee AND 1099 her as a contractor for mt business? Technically,  she DOES both. I‚Äôve had 2 different accountants tell me I CAN do both, and some paychecks would be W2/withholding, and some would be the contracted one (not withholding). Has anyone done this before? I‚Äôm still learning the ins and outs of business and finances, and do not want to overcomplicate anything if there are no benefits to both parties.

comments.text: I would keep them under W2 since you dictate what they do.

I wouldn‚Äôt over complicate it. Pick one. Go with it. 

Personally, I would make her an employee of the business and expense it all out.

post_text: I have a Med B mobile practice and employ 2 other W2 PTs. I am looking to add another PT and have an interested candidate. However, they have started a mobile practice of their own. Her schedule has started slow, so she is looking at the possibility of contracting with me. Has anyone else had this situation, and if so, how do you set boundaries with patients that you provide them to ensure they stay within your practice even when they want to return after being discharged? Or is this just not a good option?

comments.text: I wouldn't want to invest the time, money, and energy into training someone to work for me who is essentially planning to leave (and then become a competitor) once they had the opportunity. Then you'll just have to spend more time, money, energy into finding and training her replacement.

I would be honest with the employee and ask them to not solicit patients and basically make it a condition of their employment. Yes, you are working on the ‚Äúhonor system‚Äù, but it‚Äôs the best you are going to get.

post_text:
PSA - Something to think about when you are wanting to hire a therapist.

I'm going to share this comment I made on a job posting on this page.  I am not looking for a job, but I was reading the description thinking how it sounded like a great opportunity for someone.  And then the last line.  Masters or Doctorate degree required.  My comment to him and something for you to think about if you are looking to hire a therapist:
-------
"This makes me sad to that you are looking only for Masters or Doctorate therapists. I saw a job posting for a company recently that was looking for a Masters "or better." How extremely offensive to older therapists who went to school before PTs were required to be Masters/Doctorate level and so they have a "just have a BS." You could have someone with years of experience with various certifications who could meet all of those other requirements and you aren't willing to even consider them? You think they aren't smart enough? Are you being "ageist" and thinking they are "old" and you assume they won't match your "vibe." Actually, it doesn't make me sad. It makes me mad. How rude. And, yes, I "just have a B.S."
-------
This mindset is alienating to people who could maybe be the best employees you have ever had.  I know some amazing therapists who only have a B.S.  If you require a MPT or DPT, you have indicated a BSPT is not good enough for you.  In that case, hopefully you have an abundance of Masters/Doctorate level therapists in your area and you won't have to end up settling for a BSPT (who is a Physical Therapist who graduated from an accredited school and passed a licensure exam just like you) as you apparently don't respect them.  And who wants to be on a team when they are looked down upon as inferior because they are defined by their degree and not the experience they have to bring to the table?

Yes, a nerve was touched this morning.

comments.text:
I graduated with BSPT 1999. Had to go back to tDPT for several reasons, one is for immigration purposes, second to keep up with newer graduates. Third, I needed the CEU and it counts towards your CEU requirements anyway. Why would a company hire a foreign trained short Filipino good looking guy versus a new younger US trained DPT. I had to compete, I had to be at par with the new graduates. They aren't just going to hire me because of my looks and physically fit body. Just kidding. üòÅüòÅüòÅ

Kidding aside, US immigration itself discriminates, they won't let us practice without having DPT degree now (or at least a master's level). So it's not just employers who do this. Immigration, even patients looks for the letter DR when they looks us up. 

With that being said, I prefer experienced therapists over new graduates, but we also have to give a chance to the younger up and coming new generation. They will be the future of this profession and need to be supported too. 

And as a clinic owner who hires DPTs, RPT, MsPT, PTA, OTR etc. I have a 60 something year old PT and a 26 year old new grad PTA. 

As long as you have the necessary license and appropriate fair salary expectations and know how to take care and treat my patients. Why not.  Let's get you onboard. üòÉüòÉüòÉ

Good luck! And I am going to find the Michael Jackson meme with popcorn now. üòÅüòÅüòÅ

I agree with your point. Let the interview tease out desired skill sets for the position. I know BSPT's that are very progressive, have stayed current with research and are some of the best in our field. I know some old tired lazy therapists too.  I got my tDPT in 2013 because I knew agism and marginalization of BSPT's would happen.  This MS or DPT only is in most job postings these day. Ageist for sure.  What they miss is that people in our generation have an unparalleled work ethic!

post_text:
I would love to hear advice from anyone who has hired an independent contractor (1099) PT. Especially if for a mobile practice. 

I plan to get in touch with a small business lawyer to help with a contract, but I‚Äôm trying to brainstorm what things I need to think about that will come along with having this type of employee. 

Of course pay rate will be on the contract, but do you have any expectations for the contractor‚Äôs availability? I want them to have flexibility with their schedule but don‚Äôt want them to completely blow it off. Especially if I pour my own time and resources into helping them develop professionally. 

If you have a lawyer to recommend, I would also be interested (I‚Äôm located in Colorado).

comments.text: I have been 1099 for the past 4 years- as the person hiring 1099, you can not provide anything perceived as a benefit. The company I contract with does organize CEU courses under another consulting company umbrella for us, but we must pay a reasonable amount for it. Ie 16 hours cost us 175 dollars this year. 1099 laws vary in different states but they largely all say that you cannot dictate a minimum number of hours nor directly supervise how they provide the work. If you want control I suggest a PRN employee.
Discuss cancellation, no shows and rescheduled appts

full_thread_text:

I plan to get in touch with a small business lawyer to help with a contract, but I‚Äôm trying to brainstorm what things I need to think about that will come along with having this type of employee. 

Of course pay rate will be on the contract, but do you have any expectations for the contractor‚Äôs availability? I want them to have flexibility with their schedule but don‚Äôt want them to completely blow it off. Especially if I pour my own time and resources into helping them develop professionally. 

If you have a lawyer to recommend, I would also be interested (I‚Äôm located in Colorado).

COMMENT 1: I have been 1099 for the past 4 years- as the person hiring 1099, you can not provide anything perceived as a benefit. The company I contract with does organize CEU courses under another consulting company umbrella for us, but we must pay a reasonable amount for it. Ie 16 hours cost us 175 dollars this year. 1099 laws vary in different states but they largely all say that you cannot dictate a minimum number of hours nor directly supervise how they provide the work. If you want control I suggest a PRN employee.

COMMENT 2: Discuss cancellation, no shows and rescheduled appts

post_text:
Hello all! I need some help with my very first workshop. I never been to one myself so really I have nothing to go off. I have searched youtube for some examples but they all seem boring... So I am hoping for some good tips and examples.

Do you have any good resources to use? What worked in your case?

Workshop will be on knee pain. Population: active adults. I plan to briefly go over anatomy. Reasons why we have knee pain and do little deeper dive into muscular reasons. Weak quad, weak hips etc...

For "challenge" I plan to ask the group to do SL squat, SL stance (to check ankle stability) and standing quad stretch (heel to butt chick).  Any other/better suggestions?

Lastly, I plan to tech group few exercises to make sure they have strong hips and knees.
-tke with TB (can be combined in squat)
- hip abd like fire hydrants
- sit to stand (BLE, and ULE for stronger folks)
- bridges (BLE, and ULE for stronger)

Thank you!

comments.text: I've done a ton of workshops. We go over anatomy, common causes and try and find someone we think may do well with a 5-minute treatment miracle. Keep it simple, easy terms, give practical things they can go home with. Happy to chat. DM me
Check out MMOA.  Modern Management of the Older Adult.  The have very good resources for several  workshops!

post_text: Anyone have any tips for hiring another PT or PTA and how they started the process? I am getting a bit busier than I can handle and am starting to file a back log for PT orders!!!

comments.text:
1. Turn the clock back and start looking a month ago
2.  Ask around. What PT‚Äôs, PTA‚Äôs do you know who you can make them an offer. Can you cherry-pick the best?  You may find that someone is ready to make a change, but they are remaining quiet.  I was ‚Äúcherry-picked‚Äù for my last 3 corporate jobs
3. Look for someone who is bought into your mission and how you operate.  Don‚Äôt go for the first warm body. 
4. Be selective.  Seek a rock star personality.  Skills can be learned.  Attitude is important
Any PT or PTA schools nearby you can inquire with? Our local schools usually send out emails to their alums and potential grads

post_text:
Business can be simple.

We have been talking a lot at Uncaged about what it looks like to have a ‚Äúboring‚Äù business.

A business that:
- 1) has a way to manage your money properly
- 2) brings in leads efficiently
- 3) Has a sales process that works
- 4) Delivers an exceptional service and is able to measure how effective the delivery is

We should be focusing on building simple, effective, and ‚Äúboring‚Äù businesses.

Nothing flashy, which isn‚Äôt always sexy to business owners, but rather something that is truly sustainable for your business and your life.

POST: Business can be simple.

We have been talking a lot at Uncaged about what it looks like to have a ‚Äúboring‚Äù business.

A business that:
- 1) has a way to manage your money properly
- 2) brings in leads efficiently
- 3) Has a sales process that works
- 4) Delivers an exceptional service and is able to measure how effective the delivery is

We should be focusing on building simple, effective, and ‚Äúboring‚Äù businesses.

Nothing flashy, which isn‚Äôt always sexy to business owners, but rather something that is truly sustainable for your business and your life. 

Which area above (1-4) do you need to work on becoming more simple, effective, and ‚Äúboring‚Äù?

post_text:
Hi friends! I'm looking for advice on whether I should be hiring contractors or employees for a mobile pediatric PT practice in California. Moreso, am I allowed to hire contractors? 

In CA, there is this ABC test that helps classify workers and it doesn't seem like any PT for a PT practice could be a contractor then? https://www.dir.ca.gov/dlse/faq_independentcontractor.htm

"Under the ABC test, a worker is considered an employee and not an independent contractor, unless the hiring entity satisfies all three of the following conditions:
1. The worker is free from the control and direction of the hiring entity in connection with the performance of the work, both under the contract for the performance of the work and in fact;
2.The worker performs work that is outside the usual course of the hiring entity‚Äôs business; and
3. The worker is customarily engaged in an independently established trade, occupation, or business of the same nature as that involved in the work performed."

Help please :(

Thank you in advance!!

comments.text: I think the C part puts a dent in that plan. I have several friends who had to deal with pretty expensive lawsuits for this. If you can make the numbers work, just make them employees and move on. Ôøº
what I will say is if there is ever any disagreement about classifying, the state will ALWAYS side with making them w2 vs 1099.

post_text:
Hey everyone! 

When hiring a contract PTA (W2/1099 contractor), what have you been responsive for as the employer and what have you had the independent contractor be responsible regarding:

Lliability insurance
NPI (secondary needed if they work at another facility?)
Workers comp insurance? 
Reimbursing for Mileage (if mobile)

Thanks!

comments.text: I was under the impression that a PTA could not be an independent contractor as they have to work under your license, so they must be a W2 employee...

A contractor must be either/or W2 or 1099. I do not provide anything for the 1099 other than a higher rate. A 1099 is able to write off the cost of liability insurance, equipment, and mileage. A W2 cannot.
I do have workers comp for them only because some of our contracted home health agencies require it for their certifications (CHAPS or JACHO)

comments.text: HPSO tends to be more expensive, but to their credit the policy they provided me includes cyber, professional, and general all in one policy. post_text: Has anyone hired a company to work on their SEO or marketing?  Did you have to do a 1099 for their business?  Thanks!

comments.text: It‚Äôs very possible you can 1099 them, and should if you can so that way you don‚Äôt have to pay employee taxes. But ask your tax preparer first! I wanted to 1099 my PRN providers but I was told I definitely could not in my state and have to W2 them.

I do SEO and if you pay thru a cc processor you do not need to do a 1099, as that income is reported by the processor. If they are a corporation you never need to. If LLC, partnership, or sole proprietor then you might if you paid via check, transfer, or cash and total was over $600. I'd dbl check with your accountant to be 100% sure.

full_thread_text:

COMMENT 2: I do SEO and if you pay thru a cc processor you do not need to do a 1099, as that income is reported by the processor. If they are a corporation you never need to. If LLC, partnership, or sole proprietor then you might if you paid via check, transfer, or cash and total was over $600. I'd dbl check with your accountant to be 100% sure.

post_text: To clinicians who've had to be out of office for 4 weeks and work solo: how did you go about referring patients who needed seen while you were away, did you lose patients, what was it like to rebuild your caseload? Thanks!

comments.text:
Most of my clients have preferred to wait until I return, so rebuilding a caseload isn‚Äôt a problem.  

If needed, I referred my clients to other local practitioners if needed ‚Äî a mix of other cash PTs, insurance-based PT, and chiro.

I found that being out really isn‚Äôt a problem.  Most folks have been to other providers they can return to or already see multiple people. 

Initially I tried to hire another PT, but that didn‚Äôt workout.  I‚Äôve learned that I‚Äôm best working independently.

I had to get an independent contractor with the same credentials cover for me while I underwent emergency appendectomy. I think its always prudent to have a good relationship with a contractor who has same credentials as you.

full_thread_text:
POST: To clinicians who've had to be out of office for 4 weeks and work solo: how did you go about referring patients who needed seen while you were away, did you lose patients, what was it like to rebuild your caseload? Thanks!

COMMENT 1: Most of my clients have preferred to wait until I return, so rebuilding a caseload isn‚Äôt a problem.  

If needed, I referred my clients to other local practitioners if needed ‚Äî a mix of other cash PTs, insurance-based PT, and chiro.

I found that being out really isn‚Äôt a problem.  Most folks have been to other providers they can return to or already see multiple people. 

Initially I tried to hire another PT, but that didn‚Äôt workout.  I‚Äôve learned that I‚Äôm best working independently.

COMMENT 2: I had to get an independent contractor with the same credentials cover for me while I underwent emergency appendectomy. I think its always prudent to have a good relationship with a contractor who has same credentials as you.

Have any of my fellow uncaged mamas or expecting mamas taken out a short term disability policy? How are you handling maternity leave if taking it? will you try to hire a PRN or full time clinician to help?

post_text:
Hello everyone! Happy new year.

I wanted to get advice on how to manage being busy. I have gotten very very busy, to the point where I have patients on a waitlist. I hate this because I hate patients not being able to get in. Subconsciously I just feel bad and that people will talk bad about how they can‚Äôt get in.

But what I really need advice for is:

1. how I can have my secretary/front office person manage better with so much going on and with scheduling. And how to properly explain to patients that we will get them in as soon as we can. Are there any iMac applications or softwares we can buy where we can create a daily checklist to follow so we don‚Äôt miss anything?

2. As far as when talking to the patients, because we have some patients who can‚Äôt get the times that they want or have to come very early or very late, any advice on how to manage this?

3. We get a lot of referrals via primary cares and word of mouth, how do we handle it now that we are so busy? I cannot fathom the idea of telling physicians to stop sending patients as I don‚Äôt want to hurt the relationships we have with them.

4. I know the big obvious answer is to hire someone, and I‚Äôve been looking (definitely not hard enough) but any advice on this too? I don‚Äôt live in a super popular big city so it‚Äôs definitely not going to be a first choice for a lot of people. But I looked hard last summer to hire someone and had no luck at all.

Thanks everyone and look forward to hearing your advice. Thanks!

comments.text: Hire and work on the systems up front and with the hire.  So they keep the level that you patients have come to expect.  Checklist, for what. What is the goal of making sure nothing is missed.  What might your frond office miss.  Automate that process where you can

Always easy to say hire, not as easily done, but get the process started. What a phenomenal  problem to have!! Congratulations!! Be proud! One way to handle this is to consider your perfect/ideal patient  and start prioritizing  that way. As therapist we always want to help everyone, however, that's not possible. This is a great time for you to streamline and determine what you really want your business to become. You have options now without a doubt. If there is a population that lights your fire as a practitioner go that direction or, even if it is challenging for therapist to change their perspective this way, go towards an area of practice which increases your profitability. Is that insurance, or a population who would prefer to pay per service instead of insurance, or pay for additional alternative/ non-insurance reimbursed treatments? You are in high demand and you shouldn't feel bad about that, not for one second! Make sure your front desk handles it with Grace and with empathy but also not with shame. If you give the perspective that you are doing something wrong by not getting everyone in the door right away, the takeaway will be a negative. Flip it so that the wait list is a positive and one that creates further desire for the patient to want to wait

post_text: Hi everyone! Can I hire a PTA as an independent contractor for my mostly med B mobile practice in NJ ? I am a PT and will be available on call or video call as needed. TIA

comments.text: Absolutely üíØ you do the evaluation and then you have your PTA work with them. Those are the rules in NJ where you longer have to be on sit and just be reachable by phone. üëç

As of right now under the PHE, you can provide virtual supervision for PTAs.   As for hiring them as a 1099/IC, check federal and your state regulations on 1099; there are specific requirements that must be met to qualify as a 1099/IC.

full_thread_text:
POST: Hi everyone! Can I hire a PTA as an independent contractor for my mostly med B mobile practice in NJ ? I am a PT and will be available on call or video call as needed. TIA

COMMENT 1: Absolutely üíØ you do the evaluation and then you have your PTA work with them. Those are the rules in NJ where you longer have to be on sit and just be reachable by phone. üëç

COMMENT 2: As of right now under the PHE, you can provide virtual supervision for PTAs.   As for hiring them as a 1099/IC, check federal and your state regulations on 1099; there are specific requirements that must be met to qualify as a 1099/IC.

2023 Appropriations bill text released. Congress proposing to only offset 4.47% conversion factor decrease by 2.5% in 2023. This means we will have a 1.97% decrease in 2023.   

In addition, Congress is proposing to extend outpatient therapy delivered via telehealth through December 31, 2024.   

Congress did not insert any language regarding changes in supervision requirements of an assistant in the private practice setting.   

Congress proposing to cover lymphedema compression garments beginning January 1, 2024.

post_text:
I spoke with a lady today about doing some admin work and calling leads for me.  She would be working remotely.  She only wants part-time work and that is all I have anyway, but my concern is that she is overqualified.  Before she had children she was a real estate agent.  

I really liked her but I'm afraid my offer $/hour will not be enough.  How much do you all pay for admin that includes calling leads, using GoHighLevel, Active Campaign, checking insurance benefits?

comments.text: Don't be afraid to offer and negotiate. This is where your business and leadership skills comes into place. Start low and go up higher versus high and then you can't afford to pay here. If that made sense. Good luck and you got this!!!!

Keep in mind, not to toot my own horn, but I've taken jobs that I'm over qualified for. Flexibility and remote is the most important benefit for me. I'd take lower pay for the Flexibility to care for my family.

full_thread_text:
POST: I spoke with a lady today about doing some admin work and calling leads for me.  She would be working remotely.  She only wants part-time work and that is all I have anyway, but my concern is that she is overqualified.  Before she had children she was a real estate agent.  

I really liked her but I'm afraid my offer $/hour will not be enough.  How much do you all pay for admin that includes calling leads, using GoHighLevel, Active Campaign, checking insurance benefits?

COMMENT 1: Don't be afraid to offer and negotiate. This is where your business and leadership skills comes into place. Start low and go up higher versus high and then you can't afford to pay here. If that made sense. Good luck and you got this!!!!

COMMENT 2: Keep in mind, not to toot my own horn, but I've taken jobs that I'm over qualified for. Flexibility and remote is the most important benefit for me. I'd take lower pay for the Flexibility to care for my family.

post_text:
Hey everyone! 
I'm in Maryland and transitioning a 1099 worker to a W2 employee. Completely unaware of compliance issues here and what needs to be done to make sure I'm covering all my bases.

I currently use squarepayroll and they do have a W2 option. Anyone familiar with this transition and what needs to be done to make sure I'm in compliance?

comments.text: they need to fill out w4, you will need to send in new hire for to State.  also, cover them for wc and MD unemployment, CAQH if you bill insurance.  also add them to disability/health ins./ set up 401k if you offer that.
WC IS required in MD.  by having them  fill  out the w4 and signi it, the new therapist is a w2 not 1099 employee.

full_thread_text:
POST: Hey everyone! 
I'm in Maryland and transitioning a 1099 worker to a W2 employee. Completely unaware of compliance issues here and what needs to be done to make sure I'm covering all my bases.

I currently use squarepayroll and they do have a W2 option. Anyone familiar with this transition and what needs to be done to make sure I'm in compliance?

COMMENT 1: they need to fill out w4, you will need to send in new hire for to State.  also, cover them for wc and MD unemployment, CAQH if you bill insurance.  also add them to disability/health ins./ set up 401k if you offer that.

COMMENT 2: WC IS required in MD.  by having them  fill  out the w4 and signi it, the new therapist is a w2 not 1099 employee.

post_text:
Have you ever been worried you'll hire and train someone only for them to leave, take your clients, and leave your business hurting? 

This is a fear I hear from our clients all the time and one I've felt before. 

The reality? 

VERY few people actually WANT to be business owners. This is a hard for me to say as a coach who helps people start businesses but the reality is that most people don't want that life. They don't want the risk they just want to be able to achieve something through their career and they feel that the only way to accomplish that is by being the business owner. 

What does this mean? 

If you can find and hire someone and give them what they're actually looking for (respect, autonomy, flexibility, financial upside, etc) and they see that they can do that WHILE working for someone I can almost guarantee they won't leave. 

People don't leave to start businesses because they want to be business owners, they leave because they feel like that's their only hope to achieve  what they're looking for. Don't give them another experience to solidify that belief and they'll reward you by sticking around.

comments.text: If you hire an exceptional PT, (the ones whose schedules are in high demamd) and you really want them to stick around, offer a path to part ownership of the practice.  At some point, they themselves will want to become uncaged.  This is how a lot of Attorney and Medical practices operate.
No. I don‚Äôt hire anyone that crazy.

post_text:
Can I create an LLC and sign a contract with a Home Health agency with said LLC? 

I want to start a Mobile PT side hustle and eventually quit my 9-5 BUT I an opportunity to do PRN HH has opened up and I figured I‚Äôd be good experience outside of my typical director position. Would love to create an LLC and show some income coming in ASAP just not sure how this works! 

Thanks guys!

comments.text: Some home health companies will hire your LLC as a staffing company. So if you have PTAs who you can hire under your LLC as 1099s you can offer the agency PT staffing from eval to DC by your staffing company.  Then you can make a little bit off each visit done by your PTAs. In Florida all you need is to get a Health Care Services Pool license. $600 every two years.

full_thread_text:

So if you have PTAs who you can hire under your LLC as 1099s you can offer the agency PT staffing from eval to DC by your staffing company.  Then you can make a little bit off each visit done by your PTAs. In Florida all you need is to get a Health Care Services Pool license. $600 every two years.

post_text: Any mobile PTs in New Jersey? If so, I have a few questions!

comments.text: Fire away!

full_thread_text:
POST: Any mobile PTs in New Jersey? If so, I have a few questions!

COMMENT 1: Fire away!

post_text: When you hire an assistant as a mobile therapist are you doing 1099 or w2?

comments.text: I‚Äôm a PT & recently hired a PTA and I was advised (due to my mentor‚Äôs lawyer‚Äôs advice) that an assistant cannot be 1099 due to them needing supervision of a therapist.  So they cannot function independently as a 1099, only employee.

I would be extremely careful about hiring as a 1099. There are both IRS and state laws regarding this and many states are becoming much more vigilant about auditing small businesses for this. I have been through an audit it is very difficulty to prove that they fit the 1099 IC route in most situations for an assistant. Please get very good legal advice on this and be prepared to face an audit on it. The penalties can be significant.

full_thread_text:
POST: When you hire an assistant as a mobile therapist are you doing 1099 or w2?

COMMENT 1: I‚Äôm a PT & recently hired a PTA and I was advised (due to my mentor‚Äôs lawyer‚Äôs advice) that an assistant cannot be 1099 due to them needing supervision of a therapist.  So they cannot function independently as a 1099, only employee.

COMMENT 2: I would be extremely careful about hiring as a 1099. There are both IRS and state laws regarding this and many states are becoming much more vigilant about auditing small businesses for this. I have been through an audit it is very difficulty to prove that they fit the 1099 IC route in most situations for an assistant. Please get very good legal advice on this and be prepared to face an audit on it. The penalties can be significant.

I‚Äôm sitting here renumerating‚Ä¶ if that‚Äôs the right word trying to respond to a response to an offer I made to a PT. It would be my first W2 employee PT. I‚Äôm kind of fearful. She asked a few questions that are easy to answer and of course more money. I just keep crunching numbers and get scared I can‚Äôt afford it or the what if‚Äôs. The unknown expenses I don‚Äôt know to factor in yet. What if‚Ä¶. I don‚Äôt really want to split hairs. I‚Äôve worked soooo hard to get to where I am. This is an investment that I expect to pay out at first and get my return swiftly. 

I don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs holding me back. That little nagging voice? 
A few thousand dollars on the offer 
Counter the counter ? 
It‚Äôs not a marketplace purchase its a salary 

Can anyone give me somethin? I don‚Äôt know what I need ahhhhüôÑ

comments.text:
First, you recognize that this is an investment üëçüëå

Aside from that, what is the mission for the practice? What are your goals for your employees? 
Do you want your employees to feel empowered in their roles, to be able to have creativity, to feel a sense of time freedom, to feel as though they have a measure of control?
If you allow them to experience the good that you have experienced by escaping corporate healthcare, then you will have more dedicated employees who are happy.  They, in turn, pass that along to the clients.  
The results are raving fans who become your best marketers.
And that leads to a higher ROI.
That investment ‚Äúcost‚Äù ends up being a small dollar amount to you, but a very good amount for (her).

post_text:
I've had a Medicare question posed to me. In outpatient, for Medicare patients, per Medicare, does the supervising OT have to be in the building when the OTA is treating? Did that loosen for Covid and now will revert back for 2023?
I remember some weird supervision thing but I thought that was supervision of students treating Medicare patients.
(apologies, I may cross post in other groups )

comments.text:
#Supervision requirements are noted in IOM 100-02, Ch. 15, ¬ß230.2(c)  Go To The Source

"General supervision is required for OTAs in all settings except private practice (which requires direct supervision) unless state practice requirements are more stringent, in which case state or local requirements must be followed."

Supervision requirements have been relaxed during the PHE wherein direct supervision could be accomplished using real-time, interactive audio ...... [see further clarification on "how".  This variance on direct supervision is through the later of 12/31/2021 or end of year PHE ends.  If PHE ends this year, supervision would revert back to "in the office suite" for private practice. 

For Rehab Agency, CORF, hospitals, SNFs, and HHA, the supervision remains at "general" supervision.

(apologies, I may cross post in other groups )

"General supervision is required for OTAs in all settings except private practice (which requires direct supervision) unless state practice requirements are more stringent, in which case state or local requirements must be followed."

Supervision requirements have been relaxed during the PHE wherein direct supervision could be accomplished using real-time, interactive audio ...... [see further clarification on "how".  This variance on direct supervision is through the later of 12/31/2021 or end of year PHE ends.  If PHE ends this year, supervision would revert back to "in the office suite" for private practice. 

For Rehab Agency, CORF, hospitals, SNFs, and HHA, the supervision remains at "general" supervision.
