post_text:
Now that you are uncaged, how are you all making your business a place where it‚Äôs not like these corporate corporations? How do you show appreciation for your employees? How are your processes and procedure tailored to your employees having a good work/life balance? 
Asking for myself and my company. 

Thanks!!

comments.text:
First of all, I am grateful daily for every single person that works WITH me (I don't say FOR me). I once heard, "it is a virtual miracle that your employees show up to work. They don't have to". So I make sure to say "thanks" a LOT.
#2 I ASK them if they can take patients. I don't do their scheduling. I treat them like the intelligent, competent, adults they are. No one likes to be micromanaged.
#3 I don't believe in productivity. In this field, it is absolutely unwarranted and ruining healthcare. 
#4 I ask how I can be of service to them. It is my belief that as admin, my job is supporting the staff in the field. (I own a home health staffing company). It's not easy to drive from patient to patient, call doctors, communicate with the care team. If I can make their day easier by doing a menial task, I do it!
(I should add that everyone who works with me is an independent contractor and has complete choice over their schedule. As a 1099, I'm able to offer them more freedom)

Ooooh this is such a great question üëèüèº 
I‚Äôm a solopreneur, but I‚Äôm excited to hear everyone‚Äôs answers! 

I take hikes, work outside, say no to businesses that don‚Äôt align, and strive to eventually be ‚Äúa job maker, not a job taker‚Äù

post_text: I'm inching my way towards being completely "uncaged"...my side hustle is growing so I'm going PRN with my full-time job. I'm wondering if I should ask to become a contract/1099 PT or just stick with their low rates as a W2 PRN employee? I know there's more paperwork to put in as a contractor, but I feel like I could set my own (considerably better) rates. Any thoughts from others who may have had similar experiences?

comments.text: I'd personally be a 1099. It has worked out well and your expenses are tax deductible under your business. I don't believe the government let's W2s deduct expenses. I'd talk to an accountant about it to help decide. I don't bill through my business. They pay me per visit. I tell them who I saw and what kind of visit, since I'm paid more for supervisory visits/evals, and that's it.

full_thread_text:

I know there's more paperwork to put in as a contractor, but I feel like I could set my own (considerably better) rates. Any thoughts from others who may have had similar experiences?

COMMENT 1: I'd personally be a 1099. It has worked out well and your expenses are tax deductible under your business. I don't believe the government let's W2s deduct expenses. I'd talk to an accountant about it to help decide. I don't bill through my business. They pay me per visit. I tell them who I saw and what kind of visit, since I'm paid more for supervisory visits/evals, and that's it.

post_text: So I'm not necessarily uncaged,  but I just started teaching continuing education classes with 1 group and I'm on the medical advisory board for another group. Both are paid positions.  Is there any value in creating an llc or company for tax purposes.  This idea is so new to me,  I really don't know the right questions to ask or search.  Any input helpful.

comments.text: What Clay Watson said üëå

1) Talk to your accountant, if you have one. Get a referral to one of you don‚Äôt. 

2) Do the math because the answer might depend on how much the side gig pays you. 

3) If those positions had you fill out a W2, they are already paying you as an employee. That makes this a moot point because you are basically already classified as an employee.

post_text: Question: how does one hire someone?  Legal stuff, contracts, payroll, benefits, etc.  Explain this to me like I‚Äôm a 5 year old.  üòÖ

comments.text: That depends greatly if you want a 1099 or W2 :)

1. Hire employment attorney 
2. Determine contract type

1099 no extra bells and whistles but the attorney is necessary to make sure you are compliant with the law. Most contractors should actually be W2 employees‚Ä¶.you can, and likely will, get audits from the IRS with 1099 contractors.

The following is for W2
3. Benefits are through a benefits broker. You can find them online or at networking events
4. Contact CPA and bookkeeper to determine best payroll system. 
5. Create onboarding strategy, policies and procedures, handbook.
6. File for state unemployment insurance and update LLC 
7. Purchase business liability and umbrella policy.
8. Get quotes for adding therapist to malpractice.
9. Get someone to agree to salary 
10. Sign contract
11. Add them to policies
12. Add them to any insurance contracts
13. W4 and I9 process
14. Get ready to pay taxes

post_text: How would one go about bringing on a 1099 employee. And how do you know if you need a 1099 vs full time?

comments.text: 1099s are useful for short duration coverage such as vacation and other types of leave. If you begin to give them their own caseload you will want to W2 them. They do not need to be full time to be a W2 employee. It‚Äôs slightly more money up front but you are protecting your investment on the back end. It is illegal to make a 1099 sign a non compete. This means they could open a practice while working for you, it is actually expected they do this. They cannot take your clients but they can take any referrals of your clients.
If you have a small business development center in your area they are an excellent source to get information about contract vs employee.

full_thread_text:
POST: How would one go about bringing on a 1099 employee. And how do you know if you need a 1099 vs full time?

COMMENT 1: 1099s are useful for short duration coverage such as vacation and other types of leave. If you begin to give them their own caseload you will want to W2 them. They do not need to be full time to be a W2 employee. It‚Äôs slightly more money up front but you are protecting your investment on the back end. It is illegal to make a 1099 sign a non compete. This means they could open a practice while working for you, it is actually expected they do this. They cannot take your clients but they can take any referrals of your clients.

COMMENT 2: If you have a small business development center in your area they are an excellent source to get information about contract vs employee.

Our business has a physical location and we do mobile visits as well. Should I offer two phonelines or have just the one and have it go to either one of us which can answer on our cell phone? Is this actually a service that is offered somewhere?Ôøº ÔøºÔøºÔøºI‚Äôm currently using Google Voice.

comments.text: I like simple and we don‚Äôt use a business phone. We have two independent contractors with us and my husbands phone is pretty much the business line since he does most of it.
